Phoenixes Don’t Take Orders: Part Six
Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes
On one hand, Draco spent the night with his boyfriend and he didn’t get back until nearly dawn, so he’s exhausted. On the other hand, he spent the night with his boyfriend, so who gives a shit, really.

Winky is the best house elf ever because when he wakes up later that morning he sees a steaming cup of espresso on his bedside table, right next to a basket of shiny silver crown shaped badges. Taking on Winky’s bond is the best decision he’s ever made.

Blaise wakes up instantly, pushing himself out of bed and pulling out his expanding closet with a flick of his wand. People think that Draco is the one obsessed with appearances, but that’s because they’ve never seen Blaise get ready in the morning. Just like Zaira, he’s very careful about how he dresses. He doesn’t say much with his mouth, so he has to make sure his clothes do all the talking.

Making everyone wear uniforms should theoretically make things easy, but instead how carefully people ignore the dress code and to what lengths is scrutinized viciously. Pansy hasn’t been altering her clothes since she was twelve just for the fun of it. She’s been making a statement. Pansy’s short skirts and bare legs and tight sweaters are because she’s complying on sufferance, she’ll fall in line, but she won’t like it. Hogwarts is lucky she tolerates its constraints, because she’s willing to shrug them off whenever she chooses.

Blaise is different. His uniforms are pressed, clean, and perfectly tailored. They’re also custom made, which isn’t something even Draco bothers doing. All of Blaise’s uniforms fall strictly in line with the rules, and most people don’t notice, but his uniforms are of a higher quality, the fabric thicker and more expensive, the buttons made of teak and solid gold. His clothes say he will fall in line, he’ll play by Hogwarts’s rules, but he’ll do it better than everyone else, and they won’t even notice.

Draco isn’t as complicated as his friends. He wears clothes loose or tight depending on what makes him look best, has had Pansy tailor his clothes and cut his hair for years. He wears clothes so when people look at him they’re not sure if they want him, or they want to be him, but either way they want. Sometimes that means being a rich aristocratic pureblood with snobbishly good manners, and sometimes that means wearing jeans so tight he can’t breathe in them, but he’s flexible that way.

He wonders if people in other houses do this. Probably not. He’s certain that none of their Gryffindor friends put this much thought into their clothing. Ginny does, maybe, but she’s hardly the standard that he wants to hold everyone else to, that just wouldn’t be fair.

“Excited for the quidditch match today?” Draco asks, beaming.

Blaise twitches. “Not particularly. Especially not now that you’ve asked that. Why do you sound gleeful?”

He grabs one of the badges and presents it to Blaise, who takes it with careful fingers. “Weasley Is Our King?” he reads aloud.

“Ron’s freaked out by his first game, he’ll think it’s funny, and everyone else will think I’m an asshole.”

“You are an asshole,” Blaise says, frowning as he tries to decide on the best placement for the badge.

He nods. “Yes, I am. They sing.”

Blaise freezes. “The badges sing?”

“Don’t worry, they only provide the backup vocals,” Draco says.

He sighs. Draco doesn’t know what he has to be upset about. One day, Blaise is going to need his help hiding a body or overthrowing a foreign government, and Draco will have to help him without questions because of all the weird things he’s forced to Blaise to do over the years.

~

Harry spends the entire day barely keeping himself awake, and he’s really going to need to take a pepper up potion if he doesn’t want to die on the quidditch pitch. He’d noticed Slytherins wearing badges, but all his classes were with Ravenclaws and Hufflepuffs so he hadn’t really been paying attention to them. He’d been preoccupied with the more pressing concern of not falling asleep in the middle of transfiguration, and the secondary concern of making sure Ron doesn’t vibrate out his skin from the anxiety he’s doing a poor job at hiding.

Which is why he’s incredibly confused when they’re walking to their next class and Ron snorts and starts muttering to himself, “Don’t laugh, don’t laugh, be offended, this is offensive, don’t laugh,” and Hermione makes a high pitched humming noise that’s her attempting not to giggle.

Then he finally reads the badges that all of Slytherin house is boasting, and the catchy and insulting rhymes flashing across them and he says, “I’m going to kill him.”

Ron nudges him in the side, and for the first time all day, he actually looks relaxed. “Don’t do that, he’ll never do anything nice again.”

“Nice,” he echoes, but only sighs. If Ron’s happy, then he’s happy.

~

For all of two seconds, Draco considers taking it easy on the pitch today. Then he realizes that Ron’s see him play enough times that he’ll know what he’s doing immediately, and that Ron will be pissed he’s holding back, so he scraps the idea as soon as he thinks of it.

Why couldn’t Ron’s first game be against the Ravenclaws? Their chasers suck. The only reason they win at all is because Cho is a fantastic seeker and Anthony is a decent keeper. Their whole strategy is keeping the other team from scoring while Cho looks for the snitch, which of course means that the other teams’ beaters hit bludgers towards her basically the entire game.

The beginning of their game is rough, with Slytherin managing to get five shots in during the first fifteen minutes of the game, which isn’t great for Ron. But then the swell of music comes from the stands and the Slytherins begin singing the song their badges have been flashing all day. And on the surface it’s mocking, even cruel, but Ron knows he’s the one who made these, and that he doesn’t actually think any of these things, so while it looks awful to everyone else, Ron’s biting back a grin.

Slytherin is ahead by a hundred points when Harry catches the snitch, since it was hard to come back from their fifty point lead in the beginning, but Gryffindor still wins the game, and Ron actually did a pretty good job for the rest of the game, once he got out of his own head. People in the stands are cheering or booing respectively, and everyone lands. Angelina and Cassius shake hands while Flora glares daggers at Harry.

One of the chasers, sixth year Keenan Carrow, spits on the ground and says, louder than he probably intended, “Merlin, Cassius, just because you’ve decided to disgrace your family and fuck a Weasley doesn’t mean we have to lose to your boyfriend’s team.”

Draco is halfway through rolling his eyes, because Keenan has always been and will always be an asshole, when a bolt of red energy hits Keenan in the stomach. Draco pulls out his wand, but hesitates when he sees that it’s Fred with his arm raised and wand out. “What did you say about my brother’s boyfriend?”

“Fred!” Angelina shouts while Cassius raises both hands and says, “Now, really, I appreciate it but I can handle Keenan’s mood swings, he’s just cranky because he didn’t get a nap-”

Keenan coughs, clutching his stomach, and says, “Fuck your whole family, Weasley, Cassius’s social standing takes a hit every time he puts his dick in you. You must be a good fuck to be worth all that.”

“KEENAN!” Cassius roars, and wow, this is so not good. Cassius usually has a really good hold on his temper.

“What? It’s true,” he says. “I don’t understand why you’re with him at all. Your mother’s little mental breakdown over it was clearly a cry for help.”

His mother’s what? Draco was a little busy this summer, but there’s no way he wouldn’t have heard about one of the Warringtons having some sort of public breakdown. Right? His mother would have heard, at the very least.

Whether it’s true or not, Keenan needs to learn to keep his stupid fat mouth shut.

Fred apparently decides that magic is beneath him, because he’s closing the distance between them with the clear intention of punching Keenan in the face. Except Keenan is strong and broad and doesn’t go down easily. He punches right back, and of course George isn’t going to stand there and just watch his brother get in a fight over his boyfriend, so he joins him in doing their absolute best to beat the absolute snot out of Keenan.

Which, normally Draco wouldn’t have a problem with this, since he’s personally been wanting to punch Keenan in the face since he was seven years old, but now is so not the time. The whole school is watching them, and it’s only a matter of time before a professor comes running down to try and stop them.

A couple more people step forward like they’re thinking of joining in, and the Gryffindors match them, since they’re apparently incapable of not getting involved in a fight at every opportunity. He assumes Ron’s hand around Harry’s wrist is all that’s keeping his soulmate from bodily throwing himself into this mess.

Draco doesn’t have the patience for this right now. He doesn’t know how to use words and manipulation to stop this fight, so he pulls his wand from his sleeve and snaps, “Stop that!” 

The twins and Keenan are ripped apart, both looking rather worse for wear, while everyone else in both houses is pushed several feet away from each other, just in case.

“What on earth is going on here?” McGonagall demands, suddenly towering over all of them. Severus is still near the edge of the stage, making his way towards them. He’s clearly elected not to run.

“A spirited discussion,” Fred offers, hands twitching like he’s thinking about putting them around Keenan’s neck.

“A small disagreement,” George adds, but he only has eyes for Cassius, who hasn’t moved an inch.

“One might say we had a tussle,” Fred allows.

“Enough!” They fall silent. “What do you have to say for yourselves?” McGonagall demands, looking to be a half second away from picking the twins up by the back of their shirts and shaking them.

Snape finally catches up, but he just looks bored. The Slytherins weren’t the ones who started throwing punches, so it doesn’t make the house look bad, so he doesn’t care.  

Fred scowls. “He bloody well deserved it, and he should count himself lucky I don’t-”

“MR. WEASLEY!” she screeches, and Draco is kicking himself for not acting sooner, for not pulling them apart as soon as it happened. “This is unacceptable, fifty points from Gryffindor. From both you and your brother.”

Cassius is pale and his hands are clenched, which Draco thinks is rather impressive, because if someone said that about his mother, especially if it was true, well – he’d need to be the one being held back.

“Keenan deserved it,” Flora says.

They all pause. Snape raises an eyebrow. “Ms. Carrow?”

“He deserved it,” she repeats. “He said something he shouldn’t have.”

“Last I checked, saying rude things didn’t excuse physical violence,” he says mildly. McGonagall doesn’t disagree.

Draco is playing a tricky game, a balancing act where he has different faces for everyone. Only five people know all of him, only Pansy, Blaise, Ron, Hermione, and Harry know all his secrets, from his disdain of Voldemort to the marigolds on his hip. He has to look like a Dark Lord supporter to most people, but his house knows him as a moderate, while there are plenty of people who suspect he’s more liberal than he lets on, or even know it for a fact, but – can he really afford to say something in front of everyone, with all their eyes on him?

Can he afford not to say something? Everyone else is silent. They won’t say anything if he doesn’t.

Flora turns on him, eyes burning, demanding, and Keenan is her cousin and she’s still saying something, what excuses does he really have in the face of that?

“She’s right,” he says, and Snape scowls. “Keenan said something inexcusable about Cassius’s mother. That’s why the Weasleys attacked him.”

“A fellow Slytherin?” Snape growls, “In front of everyone? Fifty points from Slytherin.” Snape hates taking points from his own house. Now he’s going to be in a mood for weeks. “Whatever punishment Professor McGonagall gives the Weasley twins, you’ll receive as well.”

Keenan opens his mouth to protest, but Flora kicks him in the shin.

“All three of you, follow me,” McGonagall says. No one moves. She glares. “Is there a problem, gentlemen?”

“Malfoy has to let us go,” Fred answers.

Oh, shit. He cancels the spell, and all three of them take a deep breath, now that his magic isn’t holding them in place. “Oops.”

“Oops?” McGonagall mutters, giving him one her contemplative looks that makes him want to go find a rock to hide under, then she turns on her heel and heads to the castle.

Draco turns and sees Umbridge pushing her way through the stands out of the corner of his eyes.

Oh, great. She’s going to make everything worse.

~

“She can’t take you off the team!” Harry shouts, and Ron winces, probably because that was a little bit right in his ear. Everyone in the common room is staring at them, which he feels mildly guilty about until he realizes they’ve been staring ever since Fred entered the common room, sans George. He assumes he’s with Cassius.

Fred sighs. “As I’m sure we’re all about to find out, Umbridge can do whatever she wants.”

“McGonagall can’t seriously be allowing this,” Colin protests.

Harry shakes his head and says, “Her hands are tied when it comes to Umbridge. Going against her is going against Fudge, and she just doesn’t have that type of pull right now.”

Angelina finally pushes herself up from the couch to stand in front her boyfriend, eyes narrowed. Harry takes two hasty steps back. “So you got yourself kicked off my team.”

“Yep,” Fred answers, not nearly afraid as Harry thinks he should be.

Her eyes narrow. “As your captain, I’m furious.”

“But as my girlfriend?” he asks.

She smiles, leaning forward to give him a quick, chaste kiss. “If you hadn’t punched him, I would have. I’m still pissed I’m going to have to replace my beaters before the next game.”

The tension breaks after that, people focusing back on their books or conversations. Fred walks past him to go up to his dorm room, probably to shower because he’s still filthy, but Harry grabs onto his arm before he can pass him. Fred turns to him, eyebrow raised.

“About what Keenan says about Cassius’s mum,” he says quietly, then says nothing else, waiting. If Fred says it’s none of his business, he’ll accept that, but he has to ask.

He pats Harry’s shoulder. “It’s not because of George. She doesn’t hate our family that much. But, well, some families are handling Voldemort’s return better than others.” He ruffles Harry’s hair and then keeps going up the stairs.

Ron adds, too quietly for anyone else to hear them, “Cassius’s maternal uncle and grandmother were killed during the last war. The Warrington’s neutrality came with a price.”

How can that be neutrality? It seems at that point, whether they fight or not, neutrality has been taken off the table.

“Well, I do have some good news,” Hermione says, leaning against the wall and looking out the window.

“What is it?” Ron asks.

She turns to look at them over her shoulder, grinning. “Hagrid’s back.”

~

Draco means to corner Cassius before the shower, but he skips the locker room and goes straight back to the castle, which Draco can’t really blame him for, but he also can’t make himself follow him, because he’s sweaty and disgusting.

He’s not in his room when Draco gets back, but Hermione has the Chimera map, so he can’t even stalk him. He hopes he‘s somewhere with George, and not alone getting stuck in his own head. He manages to spend a couple hours slogging through schoolwork before he gives in and grabs his mirror to ask Harry to use the map to find him, but as soon as his soulmate’s face appears in the glass he says, “Oh good, we were just about to call you. Hagrid is back.”

“What? Good,” he says, confused as to why this would warrant a call.

Harry rolls his eyes. “We’re going to go down to his hut. Do you want to come?”

“Cassius,” he says, like somehow Harry could have forgotten.

He scowls, then says, “Last, I checked with Fred, he said he and George went to Hogsmeade. I’m going to kill Keenan.”

“Not if we kill him first. The whole house is pissed at him,” Draco says, then sighs. “Yeah, sure, I’ll come see Hagrid. Give me about ten minutes to sneak down, I don’t have an invisibility cloak like some people.”

“Must be rough,” he says, then blows him a kiss before hanging up, and Draco tries to look irritated, but he knows that he’s grinning.

Blaise walks in just as Draco is zipping up his jeans. There’s no reason to wear his uniform on the weekend. “I’m going to go visit Hagrid with Harry, Ron, and Hermione. Want to come?”

He makes a face. “Well, as far as Hagrid knows, I’m a pretentious blood purist, so no, I don’t think I’ll do that.”

Draco’s not so sure about that, because Hagrid may be naïve about some things, but he’s not stupid. Either way, it’s not an argument worth having, so he just says, “See you later. Don’t wait up for me.”

“I never do,” he says, rolling his eyes at Draco’s offended look.

The disillusionment charm is wonderful, because it means as long as he sticks to the tree line, it’s almost impossible for anyone to see him. Smoke is lazily swirling out of Hagrid’s chimney, and there’s a cheerful yellow glow coming from his windows. Draco hadn’t realized how much he’d missed it until it was in front of him again, and okay, he’s glad Harry invited him to come down, because he’s not sure what excuse he could have given to come down and see Hagrid on his own.

He knocks on the door, and it opens just enough for Hermione to reach out, fist her hands in the front of his shirt, and yank him inside, which is pretty impressive considering she can’t actually see him. He breaks the disillusionment charm as soon as he’s through the door, smoothing out his shirt and saying, “That sort of aggressive manhandling hardly seems–”

He cuts himself off as soon as he gets a look at Hagrid. He’s covered in bruises and cuts that look like they’ve barely stopped bleeding. What little of his face is visible is a mix of deep purple and fading yellow, and he’s holding himself in a way that makes it clear his dirty traveling clothes are hiding even more injuries. “’Ello Draco!” he says, “How’s yer school year been?”

Draco opens his mouth, closes it, then turns to his friends. “Is he serious?”

“Unfortunately,” Ron grumbles. “Can you, you know, do something?”

If he’d known he was going to be doing a healing on a half giant, he would have had a bigger dinner. “Yes, obviously.” He takes out his wand and turns to Hagrid. “Don’t move, this is tricky enough without you making it more difficult.”

“Er,” his eyes widen and he takes a step back, but there’s really nowhere for him to go, given the size of his hut. “I dunno if yeh need to do that.”

Draco taps his wand against his hand, trying to decide on a plan of attack. “There’s nowhere for you to run. Don’t make this more difficult on the both of us.”

“Is the resemblance to Pomfrey as disturbing to you as it is to me, or is that working for you?” Ron mutters to Harry, low enough that Hagrid doesn’t hear him but Draco is considering kicking him on principle anyway. Luckily, Hermione does it for him.

Hagrid looks at the window, as if seriously contemplating if he can fit through it, which is ridiculous. He could barely get one leg through it, and Draco’s blocking the door, so he might as well just accept his fate. He lifts his wand and casts, “Moudiasmenos.” Hagrid instantly relaxes, but it doesn’t really heal anything, just numbs the pain so hopefully he’ll stop squirming, the big baby. “Episkey.” The bruises fade from Hagrid’s face, and the cuts over his hands shrink and disappear. He assumes whatever other minor injuries are being hidden by his clothes are gone as well. He casts a diagnostic spell, and scowls. “Why do you have so many broken bones? What were you doing?” Hagrid opens his mouth, but Draco knows whatever he was doing was Order business, so he fires off, “Reparo,” putting more magic behind it than strictly necessary to heal Hagrid’s broken collarbone, femur, two fingers, and four ribs, but he can’t really afford to layer on any more healing spells. He adds on a scourgify for good measure, so Hagrid looks a little less like he’s been rolling in the dirt for the past few months, even though for all Draco knows, that’s exactly what he has been doing.

“Did you just use reparo on his bones?” Hermione demands, scandalized.

“Yeah, and? They were broken, now they’re not, problem solved.” If Hagrid wasn’t so resilient, he wouldn’t have used it, but a half giant can withstand a lot more blunt force magic than a normal human, and the soft fiddly spells are harder to cast. “Don’t ever do that though.”

Hagrid pats himself down, as if he’s looking for his injuries, then looks to Draco with wide eyes. “I didn’ know yeh could – thank you.”

“You need to rest otherwise everything won’t heal as strong as it was before, magic can only do so much,” he says sternly. “Also, if you ever tell anyone I did that, I’ll have you committed for insanity.”

Harry snorts, but clearly Hagrid knows him too well, because he just smiles and says “O’ course yeh will,” and pats him on the back with his massive hands. Draco nearly stumbles, because now he’s exhausted and starving, but he only has so much of his reputation left, so he forces himself to stay upright.

“Uh, guys,” Ron says, squinting as he looks out the window. “We have a problem. Umbridge is coming this way.”

“Who?” Hagrid asks while Hermione curses.

“She’s the new defense professor and a government plant, we hate her,” Harry says, and Hagrid nods, accepting that at face value. “Hurry up everyone, get under the cloak.”

“All four of us are not going to fit under there,” Hermione protests. “We’re lucky any of Ron fits under there, look at him.”

“Hey,” Ron protests mildly, still looking out the window. “Whatever we’re doing, we have to do it quickly. She’s not turning around.”

Harry scowls. “Stop arguing and come here.”

Draco sighs goes over to stand with Harry and Hermione at the opposite wall, and Ron joins a second later. Harry shakes out the invisibility cloak and hands it to Ron. “Sorry, you’re tallest, so this is your problem now. Just hold it up like a sheet in front of us.”

Hermione’s face clears. “Oh, that’s clever.”

“I have my moments,” Harry says, and Draco snorts as Ron holds the cloak up in front of them. Hermione grabs an edge and curls it around them so Umbridge won’t be able to see them if she turns in their direction. “Now be quiet, unless you want her to catch us and be stuck carving ‘I will not sneak out after curfew’ into your skin for a week.”

Ron kicks him and Draco rolls his eyes. Harry at least has the decency to look sheepish.

“Carving what?” Hagrid thunders, but it’s too late to answer him, because at that moment three tiny, polite little knocks are at his door. He gives the corner he knows they're standing in a suspicious look, then goes to answer the door. “’Ello.”

“Mr. Hagrid,” Umbridge says, pushing the door the rest of the way open and stepping inside. Hagrid waits a beat before closing the door behind her. She stares around the hut suspiciously. Fang growls at her softly from his place in front of the fire, and Draco startles. He’s never heard Fang growl at anyone before, not even him at his most bratty. “I’m High Inquisitor Dolores Umbridge. Where have you been all year?”

“It’s Professor Hagrid, Miss Inquisitor,” he says, perfectly polite. Draco suddenly realizes that Hagrid is just like Pansy. The more textbook polite he is, the more he hates you. “Would yeh like me make yeh some tea? I just go’ back, so I don’ ‘ave any cake for yeh.”

“It’s either High Inquisitor Umbridge or Professor Umbridge,” she says, and Ron rolls his eyes. “Where have you been the past several months?”

He walks over to the table and pulls out a chair for her. After a long staring contest, she goes over and sits down. Hagrid stays standing, and Draco has to hold back a snort. He’s over eight feet tall, it’s not like he needs even more of a height advantage over her. “I ‘as on an expedition ta find a rare magical creature.”

Draco looks to the others, who he assumes heard the real details of Hagrid’s whereabouts before he got here. Hermione pulls a face and makes a so-so gestures.

“What magical creature? Who authorized this? On who’s orders were you looking?” she fires off.

Hagrid blinks for several moments, like that’s all too much to take in, and Draco’s eyes narrow. Hagrid isn’t stupid. It’s possible that he’s literally insane, but he’s not stupid. There’s no way he’s having any trouble processing Umbridge’s questions, unless he’s a lot more tired than he looks. Which is possible, but Draco doubts it. “I’m a care of magical creatures professor, and I go’ to keep me skills sharp after all. These types of trips are necessary. It’s unfortunate tha’ I had to be gone for such a large part of the school year, but the Crumple Horned Snorkack is only active for a few months out of the year.”

Ron shoves his hand over Draco’s mouth, which is probably for the best, because Draco wants to scream. Luna doesn’t even take care of magical creatures. When did she have the time to have a conversation with Hagrid and discuss her more weird and improbable ideas?

“Who told you to go? Was it Dumbledore?”

Hagrid looks gently confused. “I’m a professor, it’s me responsibility to go in search of new and interestin’ animals, to make sure me skills stay sharp.”

That’s true, actually. Draco remembers the huge fight about it that happened about a year before he started Hogwarts. A portion of the Board of Governors had decided that the professors needed to increase the required combination of continuing education hours and professional accolades that a professor needed in order to keep their position at Hogwarts, but they hadn’t wanted to increase the professors’ personal research and continuing education budget, which obviously hadn’t pleased any of the professors. That had then sparked a whole debate on whether Hogwarts was an institution of learning or prestige, and the answer had ended up being both, pay the professors more if they need to do more, damnit.

He probably wouldn’t have remembered all this so well if his father hadn’t been the one who spearheaded the campaign to get the ministry to allocate some of their funds from the national quidditch team to Hogwarts, since one of those things was a worldwide embarrassment, and the other was regarded as one of the best magical schools in the world. Lucius had left early and come home late for months, in between acting as a barrister on behalf of Hogwarts pro bono, and then meeting with the Board to call half of them several kinds of idiot.

His father isn’t well liked among the Hogwarts staff, but Draco’s sure they all liked the extra money he worked so hard to get them.

And since Hagrid is now a professor, he’s held to that same standard. Which had been one of the arguments against his appointment a couple years ago – how could they expect a man who’d never even sat for his Owls to meet the same standards of academic excellence that they required from all the other professors?

The answer ended up being that Hagrid was apparently the most well known and respected zoologist since Newt Scamander. Dozens of letters recommending him for the position had flooded into the Board of Governors, from everyone from the pet shop owner in Diagon Alley, to the head of the dragon conservatory in Romania. Draco hadn’t found this out until later, but the only reason they’d gotten the dragons for the Triwizard Tournament was because Hagrid had called in a favor.

“And did you manage to find this Crumbly Horn Snack?” Umbridge asks, wrinkling her nose in disdain.

“No, the tricky blighters.” Hagrid looks so honestly disappointed that for a moment Draco wonders if he really did go out in search of Crumple Horn Snorkacks. “However, I think I may ‘ave found a subspecies of the flubberworm! I can tell yeh all about it, if you’re so curious.”

Umbridge hastily pushes herself to her feet. “That’s quite all right. I have – grading to do, you understand.”

“Ah, the gradin’,” says Hagrid knowingly, as if he’s ever assigned an essay. They did have a pop quiz last year. He gave them fifteen minutes to go in the forbidden forest and find as many invasive plants as they could carry. He deducted points for any flowers or plants that were native to the forest. Which basically means he made them all do the weeding for the day and then gave them a grade on it.

As soon as Umbridge is out the door, Ron drops the invisibility cloak.

“Hagrid,” Hermione says in wonder. “You lied to her.”

He frowns at them. “O’ course I did. Besides, yeh said we hated her.”

“Yes, but you lied well,” she clarifies.

Ron blinks. “Hagrid. Is – do you – is the reason you’re so bad at keeping secrets from us because you love us?”

“Aye,” he says, as if it’s nothing, looking at all of them in confusion. Harry looks like he’s about to cry. “Why would I wanna lie to you? Yer my children.”

Oh, merlin, now Draco’s about to start crying, because it’s clear he’s included in that. Maybe all of Slytherin house is included in that, even, and really, how can anyone who knows Hagrid manage to hate him?

“Want to see something really cool?” he blurts out before any of them can say or do something horrendously embarrassing that he’ll never recover from.

~

Harry, for the record, thinks that this is a horrible idea. Hermione and Ron agree with him, but Draco is determined, and now that they’ve told Hagrid about it, it’s not like they can not show him. For a moment there’s a worry that Hagrid will be too big to fit through the pipe, but Draco points out that if the basilisk can fit, there’s no way a half giant can’t. What takes longer than that is the five minute argument they have in the middle of the hallway over whether or not Hagrid can go in the girl’s bathroom. It takes Hermione loudly going through the bathroom asking if anyone is there, and even then Hagrid covers his eyes as he walks in, which ends up being a mistake because he promptly walks into a wall.

There’s a cold pressure against his backside, which Harry has just learned to expect at this point, but then Myrtle says, “Rubeus! Is that you?”

“Myrtle,” Hagrid says, startled into lowering his hand. “Oh, hello.”

She’s grinning like a little kid, ignoring Harry to float up and sit on one of Hagrid’s shoulders. If he minds the ice cold feeling of Myrtle against him, he doesn’t show it. “You’ve gotten so big, and I didn’t think you could get any bigger! I’ve stayed just the same,” she says, matter of fact, and somehow that’s the saddest thing Myrtle has ever said.

Harry realizes all at once that Myrtle knew Hagrid from when she was alive, that they went to school together. That’s so strange.

“Being the same s’not so bad,” Hagrid says encouragingly. “I can’t fit through a lot o’ doorways, and me back’s starting to ache in the rain. And look at yeh! As pretty as yeh were fifty years ago.”

Myrtle blushes silver and she presses a kiss against Hagrid’s cheek. “You’re sweet. You’ve always been sweet. It’s too bad what Tom did to you and me and M-“

“Aye,” Hagrid says hastily, doing a very bad job at not looking at any of them. Hermione raises an eyebrow and Ron frowns. Draco narrows his eyes.

She sighs before patting Hagrid on the head. She winks at Harry before fading away, to wherever she goes when she’s not haunting the bathroom.

Draco grabs Hagrid’s sleeve and tugs him forward. “Right, well, enough of that, come on Hagrid.”

Harry uses Parseltongue to open the chamber, and they all go traipsing through. Hagrid looks around in wonder, trailing his hands over the stone and looking at all the beautiful mosaic patterns. Harry pauses in the center of the room and faces the philosopher’s huge stone head. He hopes she’s here and not going through the pipes somewhere. “Theophania,” he hisses. “I have someone I want you to meet. Don’t eat him.”

The statue’s mouth opens, and Hagrid tenses. “It’s okay,” Hermione says, but she sounds nervous, and Ron shifts so he’s a half step in front of her. They’ve never seen the basilisk either, so far it’s only been Harry and Draco. And, well, the time Hermione saw a reflection of her eyes and then was petrified for a couple months, which he can’t imagine is the most positive of associations.  

Theophania glides out, scales shimmering in the light of chamber, and every time he sees her he’s surprised by her size. Her fangs are thin in comparison to the rest of her, but they’re still the length of his arm.

“Theophania!” Draco calls out, rushing forward. “Are you okay? Is the wound giving you any problems? No soreness or anything?”

“Hello hatchling,” she hisses, “I am well.”

Typical. He’s the Parselmouth here, and she ignores him completely. “She’s fine,” he translates.

Hagrid stays perfectly still, only twitching when Draco reaches out to pet her scales. “This is Hagrid. He’s our friend.”

She lowers her head, and she’d be looking him straight in the eyes if her inner eyelids weren’t covering them, but Hagrid only lifts his chin in return. Oh good, his first response is to have a staring contest with a basilisk, great.

“I remember you,” she says finally, darting her tongue out to taste the air next to his head. “Tom was so afraid of you.”

“Uh,” Harry really doesn’t know if that’s something he wants to hear. “She says hi.”

Theophania’s tail twitches, and Hagrid smiles. “No, that’s not wha' she said. But that’s alright.” He holds out his hands, waiting. Theophania bumps her massive head into his hands, and he relaxes, running his hands over her scales. “There we go. Aren’t you a pretty lady? What wonderful skin you have.”

“Can… can we pet her too?” Hermione asks hesitantly, still half hiding behind Ron.

Snakes can’t sigh, but Theophania still gives the impression of doing just that. “Very well. I did petrify her, however unwillingly. The tall one too I suppose.”

“Sure,” Harry says.

She can sound long suffering all she likes, but Theophania looks rather pleased with having four people fawning all over her.

~

When Draco finally makes it back to the common room, he’s surprised to find it occupied. Millie is curled on the couch, another muggle book in her hands, which shouldn’t seem out of ordinary, but this seems late, even for her. But she’s not alone. Pansy is seated on the other end of the couch, a sketchbook in her hand and a dozen or so crumpled and discarded pages around her.  Millie looks up when he walks in, but Pansy doesn’t seem to even notice. Millie jerks her head towards Pansy and glares at him, very clearly telling him to do something about it.

“Hey,” he says, absently tugging on Millie’s hair as he walks past her. “What are you doing up so late?”

Pansy doesn’t look at him. He peaks over her shoulder to see what she’s working on. It’s a dress, he can see that, but all her notes across the page look like gibberish to him. “I need to figure out a way to make this dress without failing out of Hogwarts. Cho and I have decided on a design, more or less, and I like it, and it’s going to look awesome, but I just don’t have the amount of hours I need to complete it on my own in time for the wedding. Not if I’m going to make the lace by hand. That alone is going to take me months.”

“Use store bought lace?” he suggests. Pansy finally looks at him, but he almost wishes he hadn’t. Who needs a basilisk with that look on her face? “Okay wow, just kidding. Can’t you get someone to help you?”

“I’d love to. Who?” she demands. “I’m the best seamstress at this school, everyone else just uses magic for it, which means they’re not nearly skilled enough to work on something as important and tricky as a wedding dress.”

Actually, he knows of someone else at Hogwarts who sews by hand, and is rather good at it. “What about Winky?”

She blinks, so surprised by that that she forgets to be frustrated. “Your house elf?”

“Why not? Half the elves in the castle are wearing her clothes, and she makes healing potions on her own and sets half my creations for me, even if she doesn’t know how to make lace or whatever you need help with, she can learn,” he says.

Pansy is silent for a long moment. “House elves don’t usually perform skilled labor.”

“Well, maybe they should,” Millie says, speaking up for the first time. “Anyone who looks down at a dress made by elven hands better take a good hard look at the food they eat or their clean house. You need help, and Winky can do it. House elves once maintained whole forests, they’re capable of more than just mopping the floors.”

Pansy frowns, but says, “That’s – you’re right. Okay,” she says to Draco, “if you don’t think she’ll mind.”

“Winky,” he says conversationally, and in the next moment she’s there beside him, wearing a very pretty dress that he thinks she might have made from one of his old cashmere scarves.  

“Yes Master Draco?”

He points at Pansy, “She’s making Cho’s wedding dress, and needs help with the sewing or lacemaking or something. Do you want to help her? You can say no, she’s not your master.”

Winky’s large eyes get even wider. “YES! Winky would like that very much! Winky loves sewing!”

Pansy relaxes, a smile creeping over her face that Draco is sure is completely involuntary. “Find me tomorrow if you have time. I’ll teach you how to make lace and show you the pattern we’re using for the dress.”

Winky nods excitedly, her ears flapping against her head. Why can’t all their problems be this easy to solve?

~

Harry is the best at Tamil out of his friends, but that’s because he spent the whole summer getting daily lessons. Now that he’s back at school, his skills have started to lag, and if he keeps this up, Pansy will outpace him. He refuses to let that happen. Which is why he’s awake an hour before breakfast with a book in his lap, taking notes on pronunciation. Neville will sometimes get up and study with him, but the closest Ron will get is stumbling out his bed and into Harry’s, curling under his covers and mumbling out a conversation in Tamil. Dean and Seamus have started using some words in Tamil that they’ve picked up from them, but they have no great love of languages. Seamus speaks two different dialects of Gaelic, while Dean just sticks to Latin, and only that because his mother makes him.

“Hagrid back and you not say to me?” Neville scowls.

“Sorry,” Ron mutters, Harry’s comforter pulled around his shoulders, and the only bit of him they can see is his bright red hair. “Was fast. No time.”  

“You were in the greenhouse,” Harry says, “Sorry.”

His face clears. “It is okay. Is he well?”

Ron grunts. Harry shrugs. “Draco healed him.”

“Are you joking?” They all jump and turn to see Hermione standing at the foot of his bed with her arms crossed. “Are you studying? Without me?” By the way she says that, she would have been less scandalized to find them having an orgy.

“Tamil only,” the three of them chorus.

She scowls, but switches to Tamil. “Studying? No me? Why?”

“You need to sleep,” Harry answers, “and it’s just in the morning if we’re not too tired.”

“Why sleep when I can study?” He worries about her sometimes. “I study with you now! And in future!”

“Yes,” Neville says, because he’s the most afraid of her.

“Of course. We weren’t trying to exclude you,” Harry assures her.

Ron unearths his hand out from under the blanket to give a thumbs up.

“Breakfast now,” she says, seemingly satisfied. “First is Hagrid’s class today. We not late.”

That was fast. He only got back last night. Harry can’t help but wonder if part of this is because Umbridge is here, since he can’t think of another reason Hagrid wouldn’t at least take a day to settle back in.

They eat breakfast quickly and are among the first people near Hagrid’s hut the next morning. He greets Neville warmly, and the two of them talk about some plant that Neville’s been working with until the rest of the class trickles in. The Slytherins and Gryffindors stand apart and away from each other, as usual, but it feels weird now when it didn’t before. Ever since the RA, interacting with the Slytherins has been a little odd. They’re perfectly polite and courteous to each other in the chamber, but outside of it they have to pretend that they hate each other. This was all bad enough when it was just Draco, Blaise, Pansy and Millie, but now it’s so much worse.

Hagrid greets everyone enthusiastically, then has them all follow him into the forest, which they haven’t entered all year. Several seventh years had been openly weeping this morning about Hagrid being back. Apparently the care of magical creatures newt is almost entirely hands on, and that means Hagrid is a far better teacher for it.

He leads them into a clearing, and Harry can’t help but perk up. Maybe they’ll get a chance to ride them, like with the Hippogriffs? He’s always wanted to try.

“Why the bloody hell is he taking us to stand in the middle of an empty field?” Seamus mutters.

Harry looks at him in confusion. What is he saying? There’s at least a dozen of them standing there.

“It’s not empty,” Blaise says, his lip curled in distaste, which Harry doesn’t think is very fair. It’s not their fault they look strange.

“Aye,” Hagrid nods, “Mr. Zabini is correct. Thestrals are finicky beasts.”

One of the foals makes a piercing cry, not unlike a baby bird. A couple students flinch, but most don’t react at all. The little thing darts past its mother and comes running towards them. Hagrid shouts in alarm, but Harry just steps forward and holds out his hands. It barely slows, running into his chest with its pointy head. He winces and runs his hands down the foal’s neck while it lets out soft whuffling noises and lips at his robe. “Friendly little guy,” he comments, and freezes when he looks up. The rest of the thestrals have moved closer too, all of them crowding in as close as they can. He laughs, holding out his hands and passing them over as many stringy manes as he can reach. “Can they fly?” He loves flying. What he’s really asking is if any of them will let him fly them. Every year he sees them pull the carriages, and every year he has to resist the temptation to climb on one of their backs.

He looks up, and the class is a mix of confused and horrified. Hagrid doesn’t seem worried, but he does look very, very surprised, which isn’t exactly comforting. “They can,” he says finally.

“How can – his parents?” Daphne hisses, loud enough they can all hear her.

“Too young,” mutters Theodore. “Quirrell? He did kill him. Technically.”

Um, what?

Hagrid claps his hands, and everyone falls silent. “Enough of that. Thestrals can only be seen by those who ‘ave seen someone die.” Harry’s face heats up. If they’re invisible, then he must look very strange right now. “They’re as clever as you and me, and loyal when they ‘ave somethin’ to be loyal to.” He hesitates, but continues, “I wouldn’ call ‘em friendly, exactly.”

“They seem pretty friendly to me,” Ron comments, and Harry has to agree. He’s been pulled into the middle of the herd, and they keep brushing against him and nudging his body with theirs. Ron may not be able to see them, but he can certainly see the effect of Harry being pushed around by them.

“That’s strange,” Hagrid says, frowning. “They’re not – they’re not dangerous,” he doesn’t react to any of their skeptical looks, “but they’re not exactly docile either. I’ve never seen them act like this before.”

“Can I ride one?” Harry asks, because they seem to like him, and he really, really loves flying animals.

“I dunno know if-” The herd parts a little and one of the smaller mares remains, leaning forward in a clear invitation. “Well, alrigh’ then.”

“Harry, I don’t know if this is a good idea,” Neville says, eyeing the clearing nervously.

Who cares if it’s a good idea? It’s a fun idea. “It’ll be fine,” he says, waving his wand so the earth swells beneath his feet, allowing him to climb onto the thestral’s back without embarrassing himself. He’s extra careful of the thin, leathery wings, trying his best to sit on her bony back. This definitely isn’t the most comfortable creature he’s ever ridden. “Is this okay?” he asks her, since clearly they can understand him.

She lets out another bird like shriek, then launches herself into the sky, no running start or anything, just one moment they’re in the ground and the next they’re in the air. She’s fast. Faster than a broom, faster than Buckbeak. He’s pretty sure the Hungarian Horntail was faster, but she might actually outpace Payne. She keeps going higher and higher, until they’re flying through the clouds, and then circling around the castle and the grounds. Students are starring at him and pointing, and since apparently thestrals are invisible to the majority of people, he must look very strange right now. He doesn’t care in the slightest. This is awesome. “You should race my wyvern friend sometime!” he shouts, and the thestral’s ears prick backwards in acknowledgement.

He could happily stay up there for the rest of the afternoon, but his class is waiting for him, so he should probably head back down. “Can we go back to Hagrid?”

She lets out a soft trilling sound, then starts making lazy circles towards the ground and back to the forbidden forest. She lands lightly, smoothly making the transition from air to land. “MR. POTTER!” Oh no, what’s McGonagall doing here?

“Hi Professor,” he says, and Hagrid looks vaguely guilty while McGonagall seems as if she’s barely restraining the urge to strangle them both with her bare hands. “Want a ride?”

She rubs at her temples, muttering to herself. “I should have known. Very first year, a couple weeks into the school year, and he nearly flies his broom into your window. Should have known. Then the hippogriff, the wyvern, the dragon, and that ridiculous bike. Of course this was next. Why am I even surprised?”

Several Slytherins have turned away to bite at their knuckles or robes to keep from laughing. “Er, Professor?” he asks. It probably doesn’t help that he’s still sitting on the thestral’s back, but she doesn’t seem to be in any hurry to kick him off.

“Those things have fangs, you know. Venomous fangs,” she says, glaring. “One bite is enough to be fatal.”

Do they really? He takes a closer look at their mouths, and sure enough, there are fangs. It’s hard to feel very worked up about it when he spends so much of his spare time hanging out with a basilisk, who has fangs roughly the length of his arm, a killing gaze, and is so large she could kill him just by accidentally moving the wrong way and crushing him beneath her. Some little fangs don’t seem like that big of deal in comparison to all that. “Isn’t that neat?”

She points a finger at him. “Don’t do that again.”

He is absolutely going to do this again. “Will it make you feel better if I say that I won’t?”

There’s a ripple of choked off laughter. He can’t tell if it’s from the Gryffindors or the Slytherins. McGonagall sighs, her shoulders slumping, “Just – I’m going back to my office,” she says, to him or all of them or the universe at large, he can’t quite tell.

Hagrid waits until she’s out of the clearing before he asks, “Was it fun?”

Harry slides off the thestral’s back and pats her on the side. “So much fun.”

~

“You did what?” Draco demands. This is ridiculous. He drops care of magical creatures to study alchemy, and Harry rides a thestral during class.

The twins are laughing, and Ginny has actually paused in her campaign to make Neville turn as red as possible to stare. Luna says, “I rather like the thestrals. It was nice of them to let you ride them.”

Luna’s always been able to see them, as has Blaise. He knows it was Luna’s mother she saw die, but he doesn’t ask about Blaise. If he asked, Blaise would tell him, and Draco doesn’t want to put him in that position. He assumes it was one of his step fathers, but he doesn’t know, and he’s never going to know, because he’s not going to ask.

“I don’t know why you’d want ride them anyway,” Blaise says, shivering, “those things look creepy. They freak me out.”

“They do have a bit of an unsettling air about them,” Luna admits.

“I have no idea what they’re talking about,” Harry says. When Blaise continues to stare at him, he admits, “Okay, they look a little strange, but they feel warm. Friendly. Like a bunch of smart, pointy dogs.”

“Enough about Harry’s recent poor life choice,” Ginny declares, getting up off of Neville’s lap. “More about me. Since Gred and Forge are kicked off the team, Angelina made me and Romilda the new beaters.”

“Congratulations!” Harry says, then frowns, “Wait, when did this happen?”

“The last team practice, which you were in detention for, as usual,” she says. “I don’t know why Angelina puts up with you.”

“I catch the snitch eighty seven percent of the time. Hermione did the math once,” he says.

“He does, and I did,” Hermione admits.

Ginny makes a face. “Well, that will do it. Stop getting detention during practice. Your high catch rate is the reason the other teams’ beaters spend half the game trying to knock you off your broom. We can’t get practice at protecting you if you’re not there. Stop skipping practice.”

Draco can tell that he has several things to say to that, but none that he’s willing to say and risk pissing Ginny off. Ginny is scary. An angry Ginny is even scarier. “I’ll try.”

Her eyes narrow like she doesn’t believe him, but that’s probably as good as it’s going to get, so she might as well just accept it.

~

It’s been nearly a year since Quinn asked him about casting this spell, so he’s thrilled that he finally gets to do it.

He just wasn’t anticipating an audience.

“What are they all doing here?” he asks Quinn. It’s a few minutes before midnight, which is the perfect time for this sort of thing, and Quinn had talked Dumbledore into letting them use the great hall, which is cool, but they’re not alone. He’d thought they were going to be alone.

“You don’t really think I’d let you do this unsupervised?” Filius asks. He totally had. Filius has been drilling him in this spell for weeks, it’s literally impossible to mess up.

Snape shrugs. “There’s the vague possibility that Quinn’s diagnostic potion will make everything explode.”

“And I need a certified potions master to bear witness to each step of my process, otherwise the board could contest my results,” Quinn finishes. Snape look irritated that he’s been exposed as doing something helpful.

“You need a ghost to summon,” Nearly Headless Nick says cheerfully. “I’m happy to help.’

Madame Pomfrey puts her hand on her hips. “This is foolish, and will certainly end in someone being injured, if not dead. I’ve invested far too much time in you just to let you die.”

McGonagall calmly lifts up a gleaming silver sword inlaid with rubies. “Someone has to behead Nick. As he’s Gryffindor’s ghost, it seem only appropriate that the head of Gryffindor perform this task.”

“Is that Godric’s sword?” Filius asks in interest. “How did you get that?”

“I was talking about tonight with Albus in his office, and it dropped out of the sorting hat, who said it’s what Godric would have wanted.” She swings it experimentally, and Draco’s not sure whether it should worry him or not that she looks like she knows what she’s doing.

He throws up his hands. “Okay, fine, but what about you?”

Pomona shrugs. “Honestly, we were having a head of house meeting before this, and I just didn’t want to be left out.”

Merlin above. “Can we get a move on?”

“Of course, Mr. Malfoy does need his beauty sleep,” Snape drawls. Draco will murder him and make it look like an accident. Blaise is his best friend, he can absolutely make that happen.

Snape, Filius, and Pomona stand off to side closer to the head table. Quinn has several bottles of a pure white potion on the table closest to zir, as well as a journal open on a blank page, ready to take notes. Nick stands in the center of the room, while McGonagall stand next to him, Godric Gryffindor’s sword held ready in her hands.

“Don’t hesitate, really give it your all,” Nick tells her intently. “Some half hearted thwacking is what got me in this predicament to begin with.”

“Oh, don’t worry,” she promises, “I’ve been wanting to give you a nice solid thwack for decades.”

Nick clearly doesn’t know if he should look comforted or concerned.

“Shoo,” Quinn tells him before he can decide, “Draco can’t summon you if you’re already here. Get out of here. A couple floors away at least.”

Nick huffs, but fades away into the nearest wall, and hopefully to the other side of the castle.

“Ready?” Draco asks, looking at Quinn and McGonagall. They both nod. He takes a deep breath, lets it out, and raises his wand. “Adducere exspiravit!”

There’s a vicious tug along his spine, and for a moment Draco worries that he’s messed it up and he’s about to turn himself inside out, but then there’s a wash of magic over the room. First, tiny specks and wisps of white appear in the air. There’s another tug, one he can feel in his bones, but this one doesn’t hurt, and Nick appears. He’s not see through, but a solid white, like a marble statue. Quinn throws the white diagnostic potion on him, and writing starts appearing in the notebook, taking down whatever information about Nick that the potion can pick up.

Nick immediately bends at the waist, and McGonagall doesn’t hesitate. She’s graceful and powerful, and Draco sometimes forgets how young she is, barely sixty, but for once she actually looks her age as she triumphantly brings the sword down on Nick’s pale neck, finally severing it from his head. No sooner has his disconnected head bounced against the floor than it turns translucent and ghostly once more, along with the rest of him.

“Excellent!” Nick cries as his body picks up his head and cuddles it against his chest. “Spectacular, what a wonderful effort!”

Pomfrey and Filius come up on either side of him, Poppy muttering spells and Filius tugging at his sleeve until Draco bends down and lets him check his forehead for fever. “Are you okay?”

“He’s fine,” Pomfrey announces, satisfied. “You are fine, aren’t you?”

She sounds so threatening. “Yes,” he says, patting Filius on the shoulder before standing upright. McGonagall hands the sword to Pomona, who pokes Nick with it, and seems disappointed when it goes straight through him.

Quinn and Snape are ignoring them, huddled over the journal and going over the results, both their heads bent together and murmuring to one another. It’s weird to see Snape excited over something. “How’d it go?”

“Excellent,” Quinn says, “Now do it again.”

All the adults start to protest, but he knows this spell, thanks to Filius drilling it into his head, and now he knows how it feels. He can do it without wasting any magic, so he should be able to do it a few more times before it knocks him unconscious. “Yeah, okay. We should probably finish up before it turns one, because after that the spell will get harder. Also, everyone here has class tomorrow morning. Besides the ghost.”

“I’m at your disposal!” Nick’s head says cheerfully, from where it’s still being held in his hands.

~

Harry’s eyes sweep over the great hall as he walks in for breakfast, and it’s a struggle not to let his eyes catch on Draco. He looks exhausted, dark bags under his eyes and half slumped against Blaise while Millie piles food onto his plate.

His confusion only lasts until he looks over and sees Nearly Headless Nick performing Hamlet in the middle of their table, using his own dismembered head as a stand in for the classic skull.

Well, Quinn must be happy, at least. Harry doesn’t see zir at the Ravenclaw table, but Snape is in his usual place, looking even grumpier than usual. He can’t ask about Draco, but he does make a detour and sit at the Hufflepuff table to ask, “Hey, where’s Quinn?”

It takes Cedric several minutes to answer, pulling his head out of the binder to blink at him. It looks like a seating arrangement chart. Cho is doing math, but it he doesn’t think it’s schoolwork. He’s pretty sure it’s a budget. “What?” Cedric asks after blinking at him slowly for several moments.

Susan elbows a fourth year out of her way so she can sit next to Harry. “Oi, Diggory, Chang, wake up.”

“Do you think it really matters if it’s silk instead of satin?” Cho asks him. “Silk is better, obviously, but it’s also ten times the cost, and how closely will anyone really be looking at the tablecloths?”

“Just elope,” Susan advises, reaching over to dump half the serving bowl of home fries onto her plate.

“That sounds nice,” Cho says wistfully.

Cedric frowns. “Your mother.”

“Yes, well, we have to have dreams,” she says.

Harry so isn’t the right person to ask about this. He has no opinions on weddings. Wait. Should he? Draco doesn’t care about his style opinions anyway, and he will be marrying Draco, right? When everything’s out in the open, and all that. But maybe he doesn’t want to get married? Sirius and Remus aren’t married. They don’t have to get married, he’s just never really thought about it. Except he does kind of want to get married, eventually, some day. To Draco, specifically, not just in general.

Oh, merlin, what is their seating chart going to look like? No wonder Cedric looks so stressed.

“Quinn,” Susan repeats.

“Right,” Cedric says, “ze locked zirself in the potions classroom. The only one allowed in is Snape, but he has a class right before lunch, so I don’t know what zir plan is after that.”

“Ghost summoning spell?” he presses when Cedric’s eyes start sliding back to his binder. He already knows the answer. He can’t think of how else Nick could have finally found himself fully headless.

He jerks his eyes back to him guiltily. “Yes. Supposedly it went very well, although ze says I have to deal with all the Head Boy and Head Girl stuff until further notice, which, ze’s been covering for me a lot since I’ve been so busy with wedding stuff and applying to the auror program and everything, so that’s fair.” He looks to the Slytherin table, “Malfoy looks like crap, but Quinn made him perform the spell five times, so honestly I’m shocked he’s even here.”

Five times? That’s ridiculous. He wishes it was acceptable for him to yell at Quinn for that, but he’s supposed to hate Draco, so it’s very much not.

His wedding speech is just going to be him calling out everyone that was ever mean or inconsiderate to Draco when he couldn’t say or do anything about it. At this rate, it’s going to end up being a really long speech.

~

It’s hard to get everyone to focus during Rabitat Aldefa, but Harry can’t blame them for that. It’s the day before Christmas break, and for once he’s just as eager for it as his friends. He’s so excited to go home and see Sirius and Remus, and the Weasleys and Hermione are coming over to spend Christmas with them. It’s going to be great.

Draco, thank merlin, isn’t going home for the holidays. He’d argued it was a great chance to find out what Voldemort is up to, and Harry had pointed out that the last time Draco was home, Voldemort had tried to kill him, so maybe he shouldn’t do that. Instead he’s spending the holidays with Blaise. Apparently Millie’s father had reached out to Draco, asking if perhaps his daughter could spend the holidays with her friends, seeing as he was so busy at work, which according to Draco actually means that it issn’t safe for her to go home, and Pansy just hates being left out of things, so they were all spending the holiday at the Zabini residence.

It’s good, he’s glad his friends are going to be together, he just wishes they could all be together, that he could invite Pansy, Millie, Blaise, and Draco over to his home, just like the rest of his friends.

Since he holidays are just around the corner, he can’t blame everyone for being distracted. He’s distracted too. “Okay, that’s enough,” he sighs, after seeing a bunch of lackluster spells. Everyone stops casting and falls silent. “What can we work on that you guys will actually be able to concentrate on? If we’re all not focusing, we might as well be in bed.”

“Can you teach us the patronus charm?” Astoria asks immediately. Marietta makes a face, and Cho elbows her in the side. “Not a huge one like you cast in Diagon Alley, but a normal one.”

That’s actually a very useful spell, just for the messenger usage alone. “I can. But that will have to wait after the break. It takes way more than one session.”

“Target practice?” Theodore suggests. “Knowing all these spells won’t help us if we can’t actually hit anything.”

That’s a very good point. “Okay. We’ll play tag.”

“That’s not what I meant,” he starts.

Before he can finish, Harry whips out his wand and sends a spell at him, turning his robe a bright, vibrant blue. “You’re it,” he says cheerfully.

It ends up being exactly what everyone needs. They’re laughing and screeching, and for a moment Harry’s worried Theophania is going to come out to tell them all to be quiet, but she stays coiled and out of sight in her statue. The meeting ends up running long, and by the end of it they’re all covered in colors. Cho and Cedric had been determined to get each other as colorful as possible, and the entirety of Ravenclaw had turned on Quinn, who had so many colors layered on top of zir that it’s nearly impossible to tell any of them apart. Draco is painted head to toe in green while Blaise, miraculously, doesn’t have single spot on him.

As far as Harry’s concerned, it’s a perfect way to spend the last day before break. Well, as perfect as it can be when it doesn’t include his boyfriend and a convenient broom closet.

~

Harry had been exhausted after the RA meeting, and barely remembers getting into bed. Everything’s dark around him, but he doesn’t feel like he’s awake, not really, but he feels too aware to truly be asleep.

“Hello?” he calls out, or at least thinks he does. He doesn’t like this place, this in between awareness. It makes his skin itch. “Is anyone there?”

He thinks he hears something, but it’s faint. He tries to listen, but it’s hard. He doesn’t know if where he is even has a sound, if he’s any place at all, and this isn’t just some very strange dream.

“Help.”

“Hello?” he tries again, “Who’s there? Why do you need my help?”

“Help,” it says again, stronger this time, and he recognize the way the word smoothes out at the edges.

He tries again, this time in Parseltongue. “Hello? Who are you?”

“Help!” This time, it’s stronger. “You are a speaker, and what I once was. It’s the only reason I can speak to you now. You must help.”

Well, that doesn’t make any sense. If only he could hear a little better, get a little closer, maybe he could figure this out.

Oh.

Shit.

He bets the reason whoever this is isn’t getting through is because of his occlumency shields. If he wants to figure out what’s going on, he’s going to have to drop them. Which will immediately open him up to the possibility of being attacked, but if he doesn’t, then he won’t know what’s happening and why a snake is talking to him.

His friends are going to kill him.

He braces himself, then drops his shields for the first time in years.

The effect is instantaneous. He’s ripped from his not-dream space into a different one, looking out of eyes that aren’t his own. He’s low to ground, looking around everything from what has to be a snake’s perspective, and it takes him a moment, but he knows where this is, he’s been here before. It’s the ministry of magic. Why would a snake be in the ministry? Why does this snake need his help? Is it trapped, like the boa he let out from the zoo, and now is trying to escape?

There’s a pair of feet in his vision, and then the snake’s vision changes as it raises his head, rearing back and getting ready to bite whoever’s standing there.

But when Harry sees who it is, his blood runs cold.

It’s Mr. Weasley, standing in front of a door with his wand held in front of him. What is he doing? Why is he just standing there? He should run! Unless – is he guarding the door? From what? Snakes?

The snake pauses, hesitating, and for a moment Harry thinks that everything’s going to be fine, but then there’s an unbearable pressure all around him, and in that moment he hates Arthur, wants nothing more than to unhinge his jaw and swallow him whole, to punish him for the audacity of attempting to defy him –

“Well, what do we have here,” says an oily voice, somehow all around him, and that terrible pressure abates for just long enough for Harry to catch his breath. “Potter. You’ve finally deigned to lower your shields. Get curious, did you?”

That’s Voldemort. Voldemort is with him, inside this snake.

Wait.

No.

That wasn’t the snake’s hatred, the snake that he’s now sure must be Nagini. She doesn’t hate Arthur, why would she, she doesn’t even know him. That was Voldemort’s anger, and Voldemort’s desire to kill, and this is why Nagini had somehow reached out to him.

Voldemort is controlling her just like he controlled Theophania. Or maybe not just like it – with Theophania it had been imperio, he thinks, but this is more like possession, like what he did to Ginny.

Both Harry and Voldemort are residing within Nagini.

She rears back, ready to strike, ready to sink her venomous fangs into Arthur, and Harry can do nothing but bear witness.

Except.

If he’s here, just like Voldemort is, he doesn’t see why he shouldn’t be able to control her too.  Or at least do something, he shouldn’t have to just sit here and watch. “NO!” he snarls, pushing against that force that’s all around him, hoping to force Voldemort to split his attentions, at least, to give Arthur a chance to run.

It doesn’t exactly go as planned.

One moment he’s Nagini, he sees what she sees and feels what she feels, and then next he’s in the ministry, his hands against Voldemort’s bony chest, standing there between him and Arthur.

“Harry?” Arthur croaks. “Are – are you dead?”

What?

He notices that neither he nor Voldemort are solid, and he can see through both of them. They’re not the pearly hue that ghosts usually are, but they are more translucent than the ghosts he’s seen. Maybe he is dead.

Voldemort steps back, looking at his hand in fascination. “Forced sidelong astral projection.” He pauses then says, grudgingly, “Impressive.”

What?

“Oh, good,” Arthur says, although he’s so pale that now he’s the one that looks like a ghost.

“Nagini,” Voldemort hisses, “bite him.”

She curves her body in on herself, looking less like a deadly magical snake and more like a pile of morose rope. “You didn’t ask. Why didn’t you ask? You didn’t need to make me. I would have done it if you’d asked. But you didn’t.”

“I’m asking now,” he says, annoyed. “Take care of him.”

“Don’t,” Harry hisses, continuing to stand in front of Arthur, even though he doesn’t think an astral projection will do any good against a flesh and blood snake. “Mr. Weasley, is there any reason you’re still standing there, and not, I don’t know, running?”

“I’m supposed to,” he answers.

What the bloody hell. Is this what talking to him is like?

“I don’t want to help you anymore,” Nagini says. “You don’t listen, and you don’t ask. I saved your life when you had nothing, not even a body, and you don’t listen to me.”

“NAGINI!” he roars, but she only bares her fangs at him. She darts towards Arthur, but not to bite, instead twining her large body around his until her head is resting on his shoulder. He looks like he’s about to pass out.

“No,” she says, sounding oddly childish, “You can’t have me, and you can’t have him, and I won’t let you get what’s behind that door either.”

Voldemort snarls, reaching into his robe for his wand, but then he seems to realize that it’s no use, that he can’t cast spells like this. “I’m going to slit you open,” he says, but he says it in English, so Harry’s not entirely certain if he’s talking to Arthur or Nagini.

“Do you know how to banish astral projections?” Harry asks. Just because he’s the one who got them here doesn’t mean he knows how to put them back.

Arthur starts to nod, remembers the giant deadly snake coiled around him, and says, “Yes. Theoretically.”

“Maybe you should do that? Bring Nagini with you,” he says.

Voldemort curses, then grabs Harry’s arm, fury and hatred twisting his already unsettling face into an even worse shape. He doesn’t get the chance to find out what Voldemort intends on doing, because Arthur shouts an incantation that pulls them apart, and then there’s the sensation that’s not unlike a portkey, and Harry is dragged back through layers of darkness.

He wakes up with a gasp, in his own body once more, drenched in sweat and with his heart threatening to beat out of his chest.

His entire dorm room is huddled around him, each of the boys holding down one of his limbs, and they all look terrified. “Harry,” Ron says, his freckles standing out against his skin, “what – are you okay? Was it a nightmare? Are you sick?”

“I said we should go get Pomfrey,” Dean says, eyes wide.

Harry shakes his head. He tries to speak, but his throat is sore and his mouth is dry. He tugs at his arms, and Ron and Neville cautiously let him go. He tries to push himself up and fails, but Ron catches him before he can fall, dragging him into a sitting position. Seamus figures out what the problem is and pours him a glass of water. Harry takes two careful sips before saying, “Ron, everything is fine. No one is hurt. Okay?”

“I hate when you start conversations like this,” he says.

“I astral projected into Nagini’s body while Voldemort was controlling her, and he was trying to use her to kill your dad. But it’s okay! I pushed us both out of her body, and then Nagini defected to our side, or at least left his, either way she’s currently wrapped around your dad. Voldemort is pissed.”

There’s a beat where no one speaks.

“Why can’t it have just been a nightmare or a seizure or something normal?” Seamus asks mournfully.

Neville slaps Harry upside the head. “You astral projected? That’s illegal!”

“So?” He breaks laws all the time. He doesn’t usually get slapped for it.

“It’s dangerous,” Neville stresses. “No wonder you look half dead. Most people die attempting to do that! Most people’s bodies freak out when their soul is missing, and then they die!”

Oh great, now Ron is starting to look mad too. “I didn’t do it on purpose! Are we all just going to sit here, or should we tell McGonagall or something?”

“Can you walk?” Dean asks dubiously.

Sitting up has pretty thoroughly exhausted him, and what he really wants to do is go back to sleep. He turns pleading eyes on Ron, who rolls his eyes, but says, “Sure, whatever.”

They head down to McGonagall’s office, Harry getting a piggy back ride from Ron. “This is so high up. Does everything look like this to you?”

“Yes,” he sighs, then twists to knock on McGonagall’s office door. The painting of a woman at the harp frowns and says, “She’s sleeping, and you’re out after curfew.”

“It’s an emergency,” Harry says earnestly, peaking out over Ron’s shoulder. “Can you go get her? Please”

The woman scowls, but leaves her frame. A minute or so later the door swings open. “What happened? Who’s hurt?”

“No one! Isn’t that a nice change?” Harry asks.

Ron hums. “I think this counts as you being hurt, Harry.”

“I’m not bleeding, no it doesn’t,” he says. McGonagall’s eyes narrow. “That’s not the point. About the door in the ministry that you’re having Order members guard?”

“Mr. Potter!” she begins, glaring. “How do you even-”

“Voldemort sent Nagini to kill whoever was guarding it so she could get past, but don’t worry, I helped stop it and now we’re all friends.” He pauses. “Except Voldemort, we’re not friends with him. Obviously.”

Ron snorts. McGonagall seems lost for words, which is always fun for him, personally.

There’s a pop, and Dobby is next to them. “Dumbledore is wanting to be seeing you, and Mister Harry Potter,” he says, and then he blinks, seeing them and lighting up. “Mister Harry! And Mister Ron. Your father is being here,” he says.

Oh, well that’s convenient. “Can you go get the other Weasleys?” he asks Dobby.

“Don’t do that,” McGonagall says. “We don’t need to cause a ruckus.”

Dobby’s ears droop, and Harry’s about to tell him it’s fine when he stands tall and says to McGonagall, “Dobby is a free elf,” and disappears with a pop.

“Are you trying to make me go gray?” McGonagall asks, but now she has on the face she makes when she’s trying not to laugh, so he doesn’t feel too bad.

“The twins are,” Ron tells her, “we just do it on accident.”

“I can’t imagine what you would think up if you were trying to do it on purpose,” she mutters. “Alright, everyone to the headmaster’s office. I’m sure your sister and brothers will be along shortly.” She looks at Harry. “Can you walk, Mr. Potter?”

“Sure,” he says, “absolutely, I’ve been walking for years.”

Ron snorts. “It’s not currently his greatest skill. It’s fine, let’s go.”

She hesitates, but must decide that it’s not worth the argument. They walk up to Dumbledore’s office, and the first thing he sees is Arthur standing in the middle of the office, Nagini still curled around him, while Kingsley and Tonks keep their wands on him. Percy is pacing in the narrow space behind Dumbledore’s desk, while Dumbledore sits in a chair in the corner, popping lemon drops into his mouth. Nicolas is in the chair next to him, sitting on it sidewise and looking thoroughly unimpressed.

Dumbledore is wearing a ridiculous dressing gown and night cap, and Nicolas is wearing one too, and its way too long for him, and isn’t exactly his style anyway. Is it Dumbledore’s? Is Nicolas wearing Dumbledore’s clothes? Actually, why is he even here. Was Nicolas here when Dumbledore got the call, but wasn’t wearing clothes so he borrowed Dumbledore’s? No, that’s ridiculous, Nicolas is more than competent enough to summon or transfigure his own clothes if he needed to. So he’s doing it on purpose. He knows about the betting pool, he started it, so is he just messing with them? What if he wasn’t even with Dumbledore when he got the call, and now the two of them are just messing with them, because they know about the pool.

Nagini hisses a greeting, and Harry’s feels a little guilty about getting distracted. He’s not even part of the pool. It seems like cheating since he saw them interact over the summer.

Ron is participating in the pool, and he’s glaring at Nicolas like he’s personally offended him. “Hello young Mr. Weasley,” he says, then frowns. “Actually, there are several young Mr. Weasleys here presently.”

“You’re over half a millennia old, we’re all young compared to you,” Percy snaps. He’s wearing too big Chudley Cannon sweatpants that Ron must have grown out of, and a lowcut, bright purple tshirt that has to belong to Tonks. Tonks, on the other hand, is wearing a dark pink satin tank top and shorts edged with lace, which are hilarious considering the combat boots on her feet. Kingsley is wearing normal robes. Harry wonders if he was awake, or if he just always looks like that.

“Shit, you weren’t joking,” Ron says, finally turning his eyes on his snake covered father, as if this is something Harry would joke about.

“They are all very nervous, and I don’t like them pointing their wands at me,” Nagini says, raising her head off of Arthur’s shoulder.

“Harry!” Percy begins, furious, then he gets a closer look at him and his eyebrows dip together in concern. “Are you okay?”

“He astral projected across half the country, of course he’s not okay,” Arthur says.

“You what?” McGonagall demands, turning to scowl at him.

Shit, at this rate she’s going to tie him down to a bed in the hospital wing and he’ll never get to go home.

The door opens, and the twins and Ginny tumble the room, although they all freeze when they’re a couple of steps in. “Um?”

There’s a crack, and Dobby appears. “I is doing as Mister Harry asks!” he beams, then he gets a good look at Arthur. “Oh, no, Dobby is not dealing with that snake. That snake is being for Winky to deal with.” He disappears with another crack.

“What’s that supposed to mean?” Tonks asks.

“Can someone please deal with the snake?” Arthur asks, strained.

“She wants you to stop pointing your wands at her, and for everyone to relax,” Harry reports.

They all look at him like he’s crazy. Which isn’t a new experience, but is a little rude.

There’s another pop, and Winky is standing there, decked out in an adorable outfit that looks just like Tonks’s, except it’s white. Harry knows exactly which of Draco’s old shirts she made that from. “Miss Nagini!” she cries, and a very odd look goes over Percy’s face. “What is you doing here? Are you causing trouble?”

“Oh good, you belong to the human I like,” Nagini says.

Winky places her firsts on her hips, “Well, there is only one thing to be doing with you. Behave!” she says sternly, then snaps her fingers. Nagini vanishes. Arthur looks relieved. No one else does.

“Winky,” Dumbledore starts, “where did you-”

She vanishes before he can finish that sentence.

Percy jumps over the desk to hug his dad, then asks, “How worried should we be about Nagini?”

Harry makes a so-so gesture. Honestly, he’s not worried.

Ginny and the twins rush over to the father as well, and Harry’s about to tell Ron to put him down when Arthur breaks away from his kids hug Harry and ruffle Ron’s hair. “Everything you did was incredibly stupid, and I never want you to put yourself in danger like that again,” he tells him sternly. “But thank you. You probably saved my life.”

The warm feeling in his chest lasts until Tonks says, “Who’s going to tell Remus and Sirius that Harry astral projected? Because it’s not going to be me.”

Oh, shit.

~

Draco is awoken by the feeling of something large and heavy falling on top of him, and he groans before pushing himself upright, and coming face to face with a huge, familiar snake. “Fuck,” he says, “Is Voldemort here?”

She shakes her head.

Blaise gets to his feet, wand in hand. “What happened? What’s going on?”

“It’s okay, it’s just Nagini,” he sighs, glaring as she wriggles around him to get to the warm spot he’d left on the mattress.

Blaise blinks, then squints. “Nagini. Voldemort’s pet snake Nagini?”

Like they know another one. “He’s not here, she is, and she won’t eat anyone, probably. I’m going back to bed.”

Zaira is going to be here to pick them up in a few hours, and he refuses to spend those hours panicking when he could be sleeping.

“Okay,” Blaise says cautiously, “if she kills me, I’m going to be pissed.”

“Me too,” Draco answers, pushing at Nagini until she reluctantly only takes up half the mattress.

If she’s here for more than a visit, she’ll have to hang out in the chamber with Theophania, since there’s no way Zaira won’t notice Voldemort’s snake hanging around. But that’s a morning problem.

 “At least you don’t drool,” he grumbles, accepting that he’s not going to be able to pull his favorite pillow out from underneath her girth and burrowing under the blankets.

Phoenixes Don’t Take Orders: Part Seven
Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes
Given Arthur’s brush with death, and the very real possibility that Voldemort might try and enact revenge, the adults decide it’s for the best for the Weasleys to stay at Grimmauld Place for the holiday break. Harry’s thrilled, which he’d feel guilty about, except Ginny cheers, the twins both try and high five him and end up slapping each other, and Ron says, “Oh, thank merlin.”
