His bed is more than big enough to share, so Ron stays with him in his room. Hermione and Ginny share a room, and the twins take another. Molly shamelessly guilts her eldest sons about coming home for the holidays, so they’ll be trickling in over the next couple of days and getting their own rooms. She and Percy have come to a compromise where he still goes to work, but he stays with the rest of them instead of at his apartment. Which of course means Tonks is staying with them too.

Sirius and Remus had been furious when they found out about the astral projection thing, but Harry had pointed out that one, he hadn’t done it on purpose, two, it had saved Arthur’s life, and three, it’s Christmas, and they can’t ground him on Christmas, that’s illegal.

Sirius had turned away to hide his laughter while Remus had done a very good job at looking stern, except for his eyes, which always give it all away.

That night Draco calls him on the mirror and says, “What the fuck Harry?”

He laughs, and Ron calls out from where he is on the other side of the bed, “I’m right here, don’t be gross or I’ll throw up on you.”

Draco rolls his eyes. “We’re here too,” someone yells, and then Draco is being pushed out of the view of the mirror and Pansy thrusts herself into the frame. “Hi! Wow, Harry, your room is so nice.”

He grins. “Thanks Pansy. Draco, how’s Nagini?”

“I had Winky take her to the chamber, hopefully she gets along with Theophania, but since my favorite Parselmouth wasn’t available, I couldn’t exactly ask,” Draco says, shoving a laughing Pansy back out of the frame. “Why, exactly, did Nagini just suddenly appear in my room by the way? Winky gave me the gist, but as you can image that explained basically nothing.”

Harry tells him what happened, endures his scolding, then says, “How’s Blaise’s house?”

“Oh, we didn’t go there,” Draco says. “Zaira’s interviewing prospective victims, so we’re at one of the Severan houses in Florence. Plus, since avoiding the political climate was the point of all this, she wanted us out of the way.”

“She’s what?” Harry frowns.

Pansy pops her head back in to frame to clarify, “She’s dating. Draco is being presumptuous, she may not even kill any of them.”

“It would be a waste if she doesn’t, they all suck,” Draco wrinkles his nose. “When she’s just dating, they’re nice, and normal.”

“For a given definition of the latter,” Pansy says.

Ron perks up enough to ask, “Hold on, are you telling me that Blaise’s mum’s little murder sprees are politically motivated?”

“What’s the other option?” she asks scornfully. “It’s not like she’s doing it for the money.” That’s a good point. Harry doesn’t know exactly how much money the Zabini’s have, but it’s enough that even Draco considers them to be wealthy, and usually his soulmate is his metric for these types of things. “Anyway. We’re forcing Blaise to go out in public so we can get free food, see you later!”

“Bye,” he says, but Pansy has already swiped the mirror from Draco’s hand and closed it before he gets the chance to respond.

There’s a perfunctory knock at his door, then Hermione walks in, a large sheath of paper under her arm. “Ron, I need your help with this alchemy circle.”

Ron rolls over so his head’s hanging off the bed and he’s looking at her upsidedown. “Okay, but I must remind you that I don’t actually know how to do alchemy. And that I don’t do math.”

“Right, yes, whatever,” she says spreading the paper out on his floor. It’s the first day of break, has she lost her mind?

“That’s my cue,” he says, hopping off his bed. “Have fun.”

“Thanks!” Hermione says genuinely while Ron pulls a face.

He takes his broom up to the greenhouse and glides around it for a bit. He was hoping there was some weeds or something he could pull, but Kreacher has been doing an excellent job of upkeeping it in their absence. Which is good, but means he’s not totally sure what to do with himself.

Well, he does have some lesson plans he has to work on. He’d written out a few possible schedules, but now Remus is right here, so he might as well ask. He pulls out his scrolls of notes and goes wandering for his godfathers. He finds Remus and Arthur playing chess while the twins are in the corner with a steaming cauldron. There’s something delicious smelling happening in the kitchen, which he’s pretty sure is Mrs. Weasley’s meat pies. The rest of the Weasleys should be descending on them at some point today.

Harry sits on the edge of Remus’s armchair and says, “Hey, when you get a chance can you help me with some lesson plans?”

“Of course I can,” Remus says automatically before blinking and turning to face him. “Lessons plans?”

“Yeah,” he says.

Now both Remus and Arthur are staring at him. “Why would you need lesson plans?”

What kind of question is that? It’s not like he can just wing every class –

George cackles while Fred frowns. “You didn’t tell them about the teenage militia you’re leading?”

“It’s a study group,” Harry snaps at the same time that Arthur says, “Now hold on,” and Remus calls out, “Sirius, you’re going to want to hear this.”

Damnit, he should have told them right away, he’d just forgot, as far as his school adventures go it’s practically normal.

“You’re leading a teenage militia?” Remus asks as Sirius steps out of the kitchen.

“No!” Harry exclaims.

Ginny pokes her head out of the kitchen. “What’s everyone yelling about?”

“Is Harry leading a teenage militia?” Sirius asks her.

She makes a face then shrugs, “That’s not an inaccurate description.”

“Study. Group.” He scowls at the Weasley children. “Don’t spread rumors.”

“What rumors? We’re in it,” George says.

Arthur rubs his chin. “Now, I don’t know how I feel about my children joining a teenage militia.”

“We could always join the Order for real instead,” Fred offers.

Arthur claps Harry on the shoulder, “Best of luck with your militia of teenagers.”

“I’m going somewhere else,” he declares and stands up. Like Antarctica, or France. If he wasn’t so busy learning Tamil, he’d start in on French.

“But didn’t you want help with your lesson plans?” Remus asks, eyes crinkled in the corners.

“What have you covered so far?” Sirius sits on the other side of Remus’s chair. “Are you teaching for the Owls or just general defense?”

Oh thank Merlin, a real question. “General defense, really. It’s mostly just how not to get killed. But I’ve also just been teaching all the practical stuff that Umbridge leaves out of her lessons, so we’ve got the Owls pretty covered I think. And if the seventh years have any questions, we cover that.”

“Cassius appreciates it,” George says. “Defense isn’t his strongest subject, he’s only taking the Newt level classes because of his mother. Harry’s a brilliant teacher.”

He flushes and rubs the back of his neck. “Thanks.” Before George can say anything else embarrassing, he shoves his scroll of notes to Sirius. “This is what I’ve got so far. They asked to learn the patronus charm before break, and I’m not sure how to really test that. I don’t have a boggart handy, and even if I did, it’ll only turn into a dementor for me, and not anyone else.”

Remus stares at him. “Well, the patronus charm is extremely useful for a variety of things, so it’s absolutely worth learning, but I rather think that they don’t have to worry too much about facing a dementor.”

Harry blinks. “Why not?”

Ginny groans, and Fred says, “Uh, you killed most of the ones that would have followed Voldemort, mate.”

Oh, yeah.

He says, “I forgot.”

“You forgot,” Sirius repeats flatly.

Yeah. That was an interesting afternoon and all, but it wasn’t exactly being tied to a gravestone and forced to fight Voldemort and all his Death Eaters.

~

Charlie shows up the next day with dragon dung on his boots, and Mrs. Weasley screeches at him until Ginny performs a scourgify charm. Tonks and Percy arrive, greet everyone, and immediately stick their noses into a stack of paperwork each.

Fleur tumbles out of the fireplace with her hair flying and long limbs in clad in some sort of reflective, pebbled material. It’s not until she’s closer that Harry realizes that she’s covered in pale green dragonskin leather. “Are you bleeding?” Arthur asks.

Fleur ignores him and goes up to Ron, giving him a kiss on each cheek and then doing the same to Harry. Hermione just manages to stop glaring in time for Fleur turns and grabs her in a bear hug. She’s shorter than Hermione, but that doesn’t stop her from lifting her off the ground. “Friends! I’ve missed you!”

“We’ve missed you too,” Hermione says, looking vaguely guilty.

Bill is in the same kind of armor, and he rolls his eyes and cross his arms. “She’ll probably take that back when she realizes you’ve bled all over her, dear.”

Fleur lets her go and steps back guiltily. She pokes at the painful looking cut that circles around her waist and curls below her ribs. “Oops.”

“What happened?” Remus asks, even as Kreacher appears and holds out a healing potion to Fleur, who takes it with a smile and knocks it back like taking a shot.

“We were running late because someone was so sure she could figure out how to collapse the wards in the next section of the tunnel,” Bill begins.

“I was right!” Fleur interjects, making a face at the taste of the potion. Kreacher pulls a glass of orange juice out of thin air. Good call, Harry thinks. That’s really the only thing that washes away the chalky taste of healing potions.

“You were right,” Bill acknowledges, “but I do wish you’d tested that theory while you weren’t inside it.”

She waves her hand dismissively. “I put up a shield in time. I just wasn’t expecting the poison arrows to come from the floor. That was stupid.”

“Enjoying Egypt then?” Sirius asks, laughing.

“We’re in Paris, actually,” Bill says. “Those catacombs go on forever, if you know the right place to turn. Curse breakers aren’t usually allowed inside, but Fleur knows someone who knows someone, and we’ve spent the past couple of weeks going through those tunnels.” He adds, more proud than rueful, “Fleur’s a natural. Our whole expedition has gotten further with her leading us in a couple weeks than we would have gotten in months. My boss is willing to offer anything to get her to sign on to our company, up to and including her wife and first born child.”

She rolls her eyes. “Unfortunately, I’m on loan from the French government. Once the gliding season starts, I’ll need to start training.”

“You’re on the national team?” Harry asks excitedly. “That’s awesome!”

“Thank you! I’m only signed on for one season, and I don’t know if I’ll do it past that even if they want me - this curse breaking thing is a little more up my alley,” she admits, “but the national gliding team outfits are divine, it’s worth it for that alone.”

Bill hooks his elbow with his soulmate’s. “Come on, we’re both filthy. We can catch up after. Harry, I want to hear about this astral projecting thing. I didn’t know you could do that.”

Sirius and Remus turn to glare at him. Harry raises his hands in front of him. “It was an accident! I can’t!”

That’s mostly true, at any rate. It was an accident, and he can’t do it, not really.

But he does intend to learn.

~

Staying behind to spy on Voldemort and fight the good fight is nice and all that, but Draco missed this.

“Since when does your family own a resort?” he asks, stretched out on a beach chair in swim trunks. It’s too bad he has to hide his soulmark, he could absolutely pull of a speedo.

Blaise tips down his sunglasses to stare at him. “Well, we own the beach, so.”

“Stop talking,” Pansy commands, wearing a pink crochet string bikini, and she has to be using magic to keep that in place.  “You’re ruining my mellow.”

They both roll their eyes.

“Pansy, I’m not wearing this, have you lost your mind?” Draco turns to see Milly standing there with her towel wrapped around her, her shoulders hunched up as she glares. “Give me back my other bathing suit.”

“I wouldn’t let my grandmother be caught dead in that tent you brought last time,” she says. “You look great, put down that towel. This is a five star remote beach resort, not a communal shower.”

“I look stupid,” she says, lower lip jutting out.

Oh boy. Draco can’t handle crying. “I’m sure the bathing suit Milly brought is fine-”

“What did I say about shutting up?” she snaps. “Milly, you don’t look stupid. Would I make you look stupid?”

She hesitates, then shakes her head.

“Then drop the towel,” she commands.

Milly sighs, then pulls the towel off.

Draco’s never noticed how big her boobs are before.

It’s also pink crochet to match Pansy, with a high waist and an off shoulder ruffle top that pushes her chest up and out. Milly has a good shape, he’s never noticed before, curvy all over, obviously, but moreso in the hip and chest. She should really stop wearing such large sweaters and skirts.

Blaise wolf whistles. Milly flushes and glares at him. “Don’t make fun of me.”

“No one is making fun of you,” Draco says, and Blaise nods, looking startled she thought otherwise. “You look great, Pansy did a great job.”

“Of course I did,” she says, “and now we match for the pictures we’ll take later. Don’t worry, I packed just as many bathing suits for you as I did for me, so we can always match or coordinate. The pictures are going to be fantastic.”

“You brought more than one?” she asks.

Pansy shakes her head. “Of course I did. You can’t wear just one bathing suit on vacation. I only let you get away with it this past summer because we spent most of it inland.”

“Which was clearly a mistake,” Blaise says, leaning back in his chair. “This is so much nicer than going to the cities.”

They all roll their eyes. He only feels like that because he can barely walk down the street without someone calling out his name or going to shake his hand. At least Diagon Alley has calmed down for Harry, but everyone is always so excited to the see the youngest son, and he’s only here a couple times a year. The only time he gets a break is when he goes to see his family.

“Well lie down,” Pansy says to Milly, “here, relax, have a drink.”

“We’re not old enough to-” A tray with a strawberry daiquiri, the exact same shade as her bikini, floats over to her, being carried by four similarly colored pixies.

She blinks.

“To the Zabinis,” Pansy says, taking a sip of her own color coordinated drink.

Milly sighs, smiling even as her shoulders slump and she gives in to the ridiculousness of it all. She takes her drink from the tray and lays out on the beach chair next to Pansy. “To the Zabinis.”

~

Harry is shaken awake, big eyes looming over him, and he wishes this is the first time this has happened to him. He hopes this time he doesn’t end up losing all the bones in his arm. He pushes himself upright, and Winky steps back so he doesn’t end up hitting her with his forehead. “What are you doing here?” he whispers, looking over to the other side of the bed where Ron is curled onto his side, dead to the world. “Is there something wrong with the snakes?”

“Miss Basilisk is not eating Miss Nagini,” she says, “I is assuming that means they are friends.”

Or they’re friends with the same cranky Slytherin who would be upset if one of them hurt the other. Harry had told the adults that Winky had sent Nagini back to Albania, and he’s not sure if they believed him, but they didn’t seem interested in pressing him about it, and he’ll take what he can get.

“What are you doing here then?” he asks.

She grins at him, dimples appearing on both her cheeks. “It is Christmas Eve, Mister Harry.”

“Yes,” he says, because it is.

“Master Draco gave to me a whole bolt of silk and velvet, brand new and not taken from any other things,” she tells him. “I is wanting to give him a good gift too.”

“You want suggestions?” he asks. He’d gotten him bright pink Quiberon Quafflepunchers quidditch practice clothes. Which was a gift to Draco, because that was his favorite team and he loves wearing their merchandise, but was also a gift to himself, because he got to see Draco in it.

Winky shakes her head and holds out her hand. There’s a bright red bow in it, and he’s confused until she smacks it against his chest, leaving it stuck there. “You is being the present, Mister Harry.”

He blinks, looking down at himself. “How are you going to-”

She snaps her fingers.

~

Draco feels someone land on top of him, and he yells, rolling them both over, grabbing his wand from under his pillow as he does.

Which is how he ends up straddling his soulmate, pointing a wand at his face. “I - Harry?”

He goes cross eyed looking at his wand. “Happy Christmas, dear.”

“How did you get here?” He demands, tossing his wand on his bedside table. He then processes the red bow, and the tag it’s tied to.

He tugs it off and reads: To Draco, from Winky

He laughs, dropping it and leaning over, planting his hands on either side of Harry’s head. “Seems like you’re mine now.”

“You’ve got me,” Harry agrees, “Now what are you going to do with me?”

Draco lowers himself down a couple more inches, until they’re sharing the same breath and all he can see is the bright green of his soulmate’s eyes. “Want to go swimming?”

Harry blinks. “What?”

“Swimming,” he says, “You’ve never been to a beach, have you? Let’s go swimming.”

“Hogwarts has a beach,” Harry says, lifting his head up to meet Draco’s lips with his own, but he pulls back just enough so that Harry can’t reach. “Love, come on, you’re killing me here. We’re in an actual bed for once, and I’ve get to get back in a few hours before the rest of the house wakes up. Sirius and Remus will freak out if I’m missing, and Winky didn’t exactly give me enough time to leave a note. Besides, I’m a shit swimmer without gillyweed.”

Draco rolls off of him and onto the floor, hands on his hips. “The bed’s not going anywhere. Come on. The water is perfect, and I want to make out with you under the stars on an Italian beach with the waves behind us. That’s better than a bed.”

He sighs, and Draco’s not above begging, but Harry doesn’t make him. “Okay, let’s go to the beach.”

~

Harry doesn’t think anything is better than being warm and comfortable and getting to just take their time for once, but Draco’s grinning at him, all excited and eager, and really, the absolute best thing is being with Draco and making him happy, so.

He borrows a pair of Draco’s swim trunks, pleased when he finds they have a pocket for his wand. It seems Pansy had made the modifications she did on his shorts for the second task the standard. Draco takes his hand, and they sneak down the hallways of the resort. A couple of house elves appear to ask if they need anything, but Draco just presses a finger to his lips and winks. They wink back.

“Okay, this is nice,” Harry says as they’re walking down, the sand sinking beneath his feet and between his toes. It’s so soft. He didn’t know sand could be this soft, and this pale. The waves are gentle and curving, and even by the weak light of the moon, it’s easy to see how clear and perfect the water is.

“We haven’t even gotten in the ocean yet,” Draco laughs, stepping into the wet sand and tugging Harry along with him.

He gets them as far as their knees before Harry digs his heels in. “Are you sure this is a good idea? It’s dark, and we’re all alone, what if the waves drag us under?”

“Don’t worry, it’ll be fine,” he says, taking another step further in. “Here, watch this.” He lets go of Harry’s hand and falls backwards, disappearing beneath the waves. Harry’s heart seizes with panic, but before he can do more than look around frantically, Draco’s head pop up about a few yards further into the ocean. He waves his hand, “Come on!”

Harry’s going to kill him.

Unfortunately, he has to get to him first.

“I’ve done scarier things for worse reasons,” he reminds himself before taking a deep breath and diving beneath the water. He can’t see much under the waves, but the salt water doesn’t sting as much as he feared. He doesn’t remember it stinging last time after the gillyweed wore off, but he’d assumed that was more due to adrenaline than anything else.

He’s not nearly as good a swimmer as Draco is, so it takes him way longer to get as far. His lungs are burning, and he swims towards the surface, coming up and taking a deep breath. Draco is only a few feet away, but for some reason his smile slides right off his face as he looks at him. “Harry. What – what’s on your mouth?”

“My mouth?” He rubs his hands over his lips, but he doesn’t feel anything strange, and when he looks at his hands, there’s nothing on them. “Did I get it?”

Draco swims closer and hesitantly reaches out, pressing his thumb against Harry’s bottom lip. “Not to alarm you–”

“It’s too late, I’m alarmed,” he interrupts.

His boyfriend rolls his eyes. It can’t be that bad then. “They’re kind of, um, just a little. Glowy.”

“Glowy,” he repeats flatly. What the hell.

“Try something for me,” he says, “Duck your head below the water and try to breathe.”

“This is the most indirect and unexpected attempt on my life yet.”

Draco elbows him in the ribs. “Shut up, I’m not saying to drown. Here,” he grabs both of Harry’s hands in his own. “We’ll do it together. I’ll cast a bubblehead charm on myself, you breath in, and if you start to drown, I’ll pull you back up.”

“If? What’s the other option here?” Draco just stares at him, waiting. It clicks a second later. “No, that’s ridiculous.”

“Listen, merprinces don’t just kiss people willy nilly,” Draco says. “You said you were able to breathe underwater after he kissed you.”

“That was just temporary!” he protests.

He raises an eyebrow. “How do you know that? Is that what he said?”

Well, no. “This is insane. Just because my mouth is glowy, whatever that means–”

“And your arm,” Draco says.

“My–?” He glances down, and sure enough one of his forearms is faintly glowing, almost looking more like a reflection of the moon than anything else. Only part of it though. Right where the grindylow had bit him, and in the perfect shape of a hand. Akeakamai’s hand, most likely. “Okay, maybe it’s not that insane.”

“Come on, let’s test it, what’s the worst that can happen?”

“Well, I could drown and die,” he says flatly.

Draco pokes him in the chest. “Do you really think I’d let that happen?”

Well, no.

“Fine,” he says, “but you’re not allowed to let go of me, no matter what.”

“I like that rule,” Draco tells him before casting the bubblehead charm on himself. He slides his wand back into his trunks then holds out his hands. They clasp forearms, holding on tightly enough that it would take a strong current to rip them apart. “Ready?”

“No,” Harry says, but doesn’t resist when Draco drags him beneath the waves. He holds his breath on instinct, but Draco just glares at him. This is so stupid, he’s going to inhale a lungful of water and choke and it’s really going to ruin the romantic atmosphere of this little escapade.

Draco digs his nails into Harry’s skin to get his attention.  “Breathe.”

He opens his mouth and snaps, “Easy for you to say!”

Wait.

He takes another deep breath, and he can feel the water filling his mouth and going down his throat, but it’s - it doesn’t hurt, it’s not killing him. He takes and experimental deep breath and breathes out, “Merlin’s sagging balls.”

He can breathe underwater.

Draco laughs and twirls them around. “This is so cool!”

It’s pretty cool, although Harry can’t help but think this is just one more thing that separates him from everyone else. But he can’t say that, not when Draco looks so excited, and really, what does it matter? Draco loves it, his friends and family won’t care, so what does it matter?

He’s always been the odd one out, even in the wizarding world, but what does that matter, really, compared to everything else he has?

“You have to get better at swimming,” Draco says, “this is amazing - you can deep dive and not have to worry about charms breaking or shattering or gillyweed or anything running out!”

Harry kicks up towards the surface, and for a moment there’s the unbearable pressure of being unable to breathe, then he opens his mouth. As soon as he tries to take in a mouthful of air, it’s like the water in his lungs disappears. “Do we have to do it now?”

Draco cancels his bubblehead charm. “Well, no, and really I wouldn’t recommend the open ocean at night for intense diving lessons.”

“Well, what would you recommend for us to do at night, then?” he asks, placing his hands on Draco’s hips and dragging him closer.

His soulmate grins and throws his arms around his neck, pressing their foreheads together. “Not sure. Got any suggestions?”

Harry finally gets to kiss him, salt water on both their tongues and their skin slippery and warm. After several long moments of kissing beneath the light of the moon, Harry licks his way down Draco’s neck and asks, “Can we please go back to bed now?”

“Sleepy?” he asks, because he’s asshole.

Harry glares and digs his thumbs into Draco’s hips just to make him squirm. “No.”

“Oh, I don’t know, this water is so nice,” he says, biting at his bottom lip in an attempt to keep his grin tucked away.  

Merlin above. Harry drags him backwards until his feet find solid land again, and Draco’s too busy laughing at him notice. Harry leans over, grabs Draco around the waist, and hauls him over his shoulder.

All those hours spent training for quidditch aren’t for nothing.

“Harry!” he yelps, “Put me down!”

He bounces Draco around a little to get a better grip, then begins his walk back to shore. “Sorry, what was that?”

Draco tries to slide out of his grip, but when he realizes Harry’s not letting him go, he just goes limp. “Well, I can’t complain about the view at least.”

Harry doesn’t get it until Draco slaps his ass. “Hey!”

“You’re lucky I didn’t bite it,” he says magnanimously

Harry carries him all the way back to his room, waving cheerfully to several amused house elves along the way.  

~

Winky drops him back off just before dawn, and he crawls back into bed exhausted and content and happy. This was stupidly risky, and they really can’t do it again, they shouldn’t have even done it once. But it was nice and good, he can’t make himself regret it.

Up until Ron wakes him up and pulls him out of bed at seven in the morning. “What’s wrong with you? It’s Christmas!” He’s practically dragging Harry down the hallway.

“Just didn’t sleep much,” he says, because other doors are opening up, people stumbling out of their bedroom. Ron gives him a skeptical look, so Harry winks at him. He’ll tell Ron and Hermione later.

Obviously he and Draco still have to be a secret, for so many reasons, but they could tell the others that they’re dating, at least, right? The twins, Neville, Ginny, Luna, and Milly. He’s pretty sure at least Luna knows already, she seems to know everything, and he’s pretty sure half of them think he and Draco are in some sort of dramatic unrealized star crossed love story, when actually they’re in the middle of a dramatic star crossed love story and are very, very aware of it.

Then again, that opens the question of soulmates back up again, because the whole wizarding world knows that Harry has a soulmark, and he assumes both Luna and Milly know that Draco has one, since before second year neither of them had gone to any great lengths to hide it. They hadn’t flaunted it, which was good, since probably someone would have noticed if they’d gone from showing it off to keeping it covered all the time.

They are so, so lucky that they’re marks in a place that’s easy to hide. Otherwise they have wouldn’t have been able to get away with any of this.

“Nathaar Vaalthukal,” Remus says, ruffling his hair. Sirius smiles at him from where he’s hunched over a cup of coffee, clearly still half asleep.

“Nathaar Vaalthukal!” a chorus of voices greets him, all his friends who’ve gone to the effort to learn his language with him, so he wouldn’t have to discover his father’s heritage all on his own.

Okay, there’s the whole Umbridge trying to ruin his life, having a secret soulmate, and a madman trying to kill him thing, but besides that, he’d say his life is going pretty great.

~

Once they all return to Hogwarts, things fall into a familiar pattern for Draco. Quidditch practice, classes, assisting Filius and working on his second academic paper, and studying with Pomfrey. Then the secret RA lessons, and the even more secret meeting with the Gryffindors, and those rare moments he can snatch alone with Harry. There’s also the added fun of trying to hide a giant magical snake in his room, since Nagini keeps sneaking away from the chamber to nap in his trunk. Thank merlin Blaise is unphased by just about everything, including this.

Which is why it takes him a while to notice that something is happening with Umbridge. By which he means, he doesn’t notice at all, and Milly and Pansy are the ones that bring it up at one of their late night meetings with the others.

“She’s planning to do something awful to Trelawney,” Milly insists. “She’s attending pretty much all of her classes.”

“Same with Hagrid,” Pansy points out. “Who she obviously hates.”

Ron looks up from the alchemy circle he’s helping Hermione sketch out. “Okay, but is doing something awful to Trelawney really that bad? She’s terrible.”

“She’s a real prophet!” Milly says. “Well, according to my aunt she is, and she works in the Department of Mysteries, so she’d know.”

Ron shrugs. “Yeah, sure. So assuming that’s the case and she just doesn’t have a few screws loose and a sore throat, it’s not something she was taught, it’s something she is. It’s like having Hagrid teach a weight lifting class. He wouldn’t know where to start when it comes to teaching someone how to get strong, because he just is strong, no effort needed, and has no idea how anyone goes about doing it in a purposeful kind of way.”

“You all know what I think about divination,” Hermione says, and Ginny snorts, because the whole school knows how she feels about divination. Possibly all of magical Britain knows how she feels about divination. “But Ron has a point. Just because she can do, doesn’t mean that she can teach.”

“And I’m still pretty suspect on her ability to do,” Ron says. “How many propheters have turned out to be crazy and just vague enough that people can pretend they actually foretold something? I feel like the answer is a kind of a lot.”

Pansy and Milly turn to Draco and he raises his hands in front of him. “Look. Obviously Umbridge exerting power and influence over the school is bad. However. Getting rid of Trelawney wouldn’t be the worst thing. Dad’s been trying to do that for about a decade.”

Blaise frowns. “Actually, how did she even get appointed? Hagrid was a struggle, and frankly there isn’t anyone more qualified. As opposed to Trelawney, who’s barely qualified to pretend to read auras in the corner of a muggle bookshop.”

“Dumbledore did it right when the war ended,” Neville says. “Things were kind of a mess, and about half the board was being accused of being Death Eaters – Draco’s dad included. So it was a lot easier to get her appointed than it should have been. As for how she’s still here, well, if she really does have multiple officially recognized prophecies, then they’d be hard pressed to find someone with better credentials than that.”

They all stare at him.

He flushes. “My cousin Caligula is on the board, remember? She’s, uh, mentioned it a time or two. She’s a diviner, and she’s pretty good. She’s not interested in teaching, otherwise she might be able to wrestle the position from Trelawney. But she does kind of consider it an insult that one of the most highly respected educational institutions in the magical world has such an abysmal divination department. We’re apparently the punchline of a joke in Haiti, but she won’t tell me what the joke is.”

George frowns and Fred asks, “There has to be lots of prophecies, right? That’s what divination is all about.”

“Also, Neville and Milly, I’m certain what you’ve just said is confidential information,” Blaise says, “the names of phropheters are kept a secret in the Department of Mysteries. She’s actually given a real, verified prophecy?”

“The only part that’s a secret is what the prophecies said. The rest is public, if closely guarded, information. Otherwise she never would have been able to get the position,” Draco points out.

“I’m just repeating what my aunt told me about her,” Milly says while Neville holds up four fingers.

“No way,” Hermione says automatically, glaring at Neville. “That’s impossible.”

He rolls his eyes. “Impossible and improbable are not synonyms.”

George raises his hand. “Hi, would you like to share with the rest of the class? What’s the big deal if Trelawney’s given four prophecies? She’s supposed to be an expert, shouldn’t she be banging out prophecies every day?”

Hermione shakes her head. “No, you’re thinking of predictions. Predictions are just – looking into the future and saying what’s likely to happen. Prophecies are different. They – they foretell the future, sure but they also have the power to shape the future. Time is malleable, and it can be manipulated. Even if a prediction is true when someone makes it, it can still change. But if there’s a prophecy, then what’s being foretold becomes a fixed point.”

“Whether prophecies create fixed points, or whether prophecies are only told about fixed points is a matter of debate,” Neville adds. “But either way, they’re rare. Since Hogwarts’s founding there’s only been about three hundred verified prophecies, and only a handful of them were told by the same person. Trelawney’s told more verified prophecies than anyone else in the past thousand years. It must be what makes her so hard to fire. She’s a terrible teacher. She just is. But, she’s also the most acclaimed prophetess in British history, even if she’s a horrible diviner.”

“That can’t be right. That woman couldn’t predict what the Great Hall was serving for dinner if someone handed her a menu,” Fred protests.

 “Is Hogwarts about prestige or learning?” Draco asks. “It’s both, and Trelawney is also pretty light on the former, since everyone knows how bad she is, prophecies or no prophecies. All I’m saying is, is that if Umbridge fires her, it’ll be the one good thing she’s done for this school.”

Milly throws her hands up. “Okay, fine, maybe. But she’s going after Hagrid too, and he does belong here. He’s the best care of magical creatures professor we’ve had in decades.”

“She’s right,” Harry says, and Draco’s not stupid enough to argue. “But what are we supposed to do about it? I’m already making Umbridge’s life plenty difficult, and I’ve got the detentions to prove it.”

“Same,” says George. “We’re just lucky we have Draco to patch us up and Quinn to keep making those healing potions. But I’m not sure how acting more obnoxious and pissing her off even more than we already are can keep her from firing Hagrid.”

Draco’s blows out a breath, frustrated, and Harry lays his hand against his back and says to everyone, “One problem at a time. We’ll cross that bridge when we get to it. For now, we just do what we can. Which isn’t much, unfortunately.”

“I don’t know if I’d define leading a secret literally underground militia in an attempt to undermine her while also slowly driving her to a mental breakdown as not much,” Neville comments.

They really need to get better hobbies.

~

Suspicious deaths of ministry officials that make the third page news? Cool. Unfortunate, but cool. What was a Devil’s Snare doing in the department of mysteries, is what Draco really wants to know.

Umbridge enacting a decree banning professors from discussing anything unrelated to their subject matter in the classroom in a transparent attempt to keep them from analyzing and internalizing the ministry’s incompetence? Not cool. Not cool at all.

Not being able to send his parents letters that say anything beyond boring generalities is frustrating for a number of reasons. His life would be so much easier if he could just ask how much Voldemort is encroaching on their manor and harming his parents instead of having to infer it from his mother’s bland mentions of needing to order more fine china. But currently it’s most annoying because he can’t send his dad an angry letter complaining about Umbridge and needling him for more information. His dad doesn’t work for the Wizengamot technically, but he’s assisted in enough litigation and knows enough people that if there’s something to know about, then he’s probably one of the people that knows about it. Of course, that was before Voldemort moved into their house and started up eating up all the time his dad used to use to dig around in ministry matters. Now Draco is just forced to wonder about things like everyone else. It’s certainly one of Voldemort’s lesser crimes, but it’s also really annoying.

Unless the two things are related, then his dad might know about it anyway.

Draco freezes, blinking down at his parchment. The alchemy circle he’d been sketching out looks like crap, this is what he gets for trying to do his alchemy homework while distracted.

What if they are related? Voldemort was clearly trying to get something in the ministry, and now a ministry member has been killed by going somewhere he shouldn’t. Voldemort’s talent with possession and the imperious curse is legendary. If he can’t get it himself, what’s to stop him from forcing someone else to get it for him?

Bode worked in the Department of Mysteries. Maybe that doesn’t matter, and he was just some random ministry member that Voldemort managed to get his hands on. Except if it could be just anyone who worked at the ministry, then he wouldn’t need to use imperio or anything else. He has plenty of followers who work at the ministry, his aunt included. Why risk using someone else if he doesn’t have to? He doesn’t value any of their lives enough for it be for their safety.

So it had to be that Bod is special. And as far as Draco’s aware, the only thing separating Bode from any of the ministry Death Eaters is that he worked for the Department of Mysteries, and none of them do.

“Are you okay?” Blaise asks. “You’ve been staring at nothing for like three minutes. It’s kind of creeping me out.”

He stands up, tapping the parchment with his wand to dry the ink. “I’ve figured something out, I think, or maybe I’m just paranoid.”

“It can be both,” Blaise says in an encouraging tone of voice. Draco throws his quill at his head.

~

Everyone agrees that it’s pretty likely that Draco is right. Voldemort wants something in the Department of Mysteries, which is also likely the thing he still wanted from the summer.

Unfortunately, this presents a whole new problem.

“No one really knows what’s in the Department of Mysteries?” Hermione asks, frustrated.

Pansy says, “Well, you see, I don’t know if you noticed the name, but it’s a mystery.”

“Prophecies,” Blaise says before it can turn into an argument. “Like Neville said. Maybe it’s a weapon?”

“It would have to be, wouldn’t it?” Harry frowns. “What else would be so important to him that he’d spend months obsessing about it?”

“Could be a nose,” Ron offers. Pansy snorts and Hermione elbows him in the side. It doesn’t deter him in the slightest. “A nice toupee, maybe.”

“Isn’t there a book about this?” Hermione asks desperately. “What’s in there can’t be a complete mystery, that’s impossible.”

“Research into the forbidden arts, and books deemed too dangerous to the public.” Hermione opens her mouth, outraged, and Blaise continues, “Yes, censorship and hoarding knowledge is bad, and a system which permits that at all is a system which can be used and exploited to the detriment of society. I know. But maybe that’s what he’s after.”

“A book,” Ron says dubiously.

“Books are important!” Hermione defends, but then says, “I don’t know what kind of book could be that important, though. Some sort of mass killing spell?”

“That’s wingardium leviosa,” Blaise says. The Gryffindors turn to stare at him. “What? Lift a few hundred stones high enough into the air, and then just end the spell. Sure, people can stop it with a strong enough protego, but that’s only if they see it coming. Add an illusion charm and sound muffling charm to that, and they’re not going to know what’s happening until they’re already dead on the ground. A particularly talented first year could do it.”

Harry turns to glare at him, and Draco admits, “My first year levitation weight was five hundred pounds. I could have done it. Well, my illusions were crap back then, so not that bit, but the deadly rain of rocks part is easy enough.”

“Bullshit,” Hermione says, and Ron laughs.

“Magic is only as useful as your imagination,” Blaise says, in the tone of voice of someone who’s had that exact thing said to them a thousand times before. It’s one of Zaira’s favorite sayings. She’s not a particularly powerful witch, but she is a creative one.

Pansy sighs. “So it’s a weapon, or a piece of knowledge, or neither. Great.”

“You could almost say,” Ron intones dramatically, “that it’s a mystery.”

Draco flicks his wand to send one of the chair cushions sailing into Ron’s face. He doesn’t regret it, even when it sparks an all out pillow fight, and he’s given the very painful reminder that Hermione fights dirty.

~

Harry is on his way to quidditch practice when someone grabs his arm and yanks him under the bleachers. “Ow!”

“Sorry,” says Quinn, “but I needed to talk to you.”

“We eat meals together three times a day and are in a secret underground study group together,” Harry points out, rubbing at his arm. He waits for the protest that it’s not a study group, it’s a teenage militia, but instead ze only smiles weakly in response. “What’s wrong? Is someone hurt? Are you hurt? You know Malfoy is the one who can heal.”

Quinn shakes zir head. “No, I - so I was in Severus’s private stores,” Harry pulls a face, and ze rolls zir eyes. “That’s not a metaphor for anything, don’t be gross. I was in his private stores, which I’m not technically supposed to do, because if I ask him for something he’ll let me have it, but I’m supposed to ask. But he’s at some conference or whatever this weekend, one of those things Dumbledore forces him to attend so he can keep his teaching position, and I didn’t want to wait, that would be torturous, and it’s not like Severus wouldn’t give it to me anyway, right?”

“Right,” Harry says, because ze seems to be waiting for some sort of response.

Ze nods, rubbing zir hands on the front of zir skirt. “Right. So I break into his private stores, because it’s not like it’s hard, the password is hemlock, obviously.”

“Obviously,” Harry says. He hopes this isn’t leading up to Quinn finding Snape’s Death Eater mask or something, because then he’ll have to come up with some sort of lie to stop zir from freaking out about it without revealing that Snape’s a member of the Order.

“And I went in, and there was the ingredient I needed, but - but there was also this thing in the corner, this huge bowl, and it was glowing, right? And I can’t just ignore a big cool glowing bowl, obviously I go over to look at it, and I lean my face in, and I accidentally touch the glowing liquid, and then - then I saw something.”

Ze’s pale and shifting zir weight from one side to the other. Harry waits, then asks, “What did you see?”

“I can’t tell you.”

Harry’s going to scream. “Quinn, I’m late for practice. Again.”

“I can’t tell you, because you won’t believe me,” ze says. “I barely believe it, and I saw it. But you - you should see it, I think. Even though Severus is going to kill me, first for looking myself, but definitely for telling you.”

“Well, then maybe I shouldn’t look then,” Harry says. He doesn’t want to get Quinn in trouble, and also he likes to spend as little time as possible thinking about Snape. That means purposefully going snooping for his secrets isn’t really something he want to have to fit into his schedule.

“You should look,” Quinn insists. “Severus is gone until tomorrow. I would do it tonight.”

“Why?” he demands. This is ridiculous.

Ze licks zir lips, opens zir mouth, then just shakes zir head and turns on zir heal to march back to the castle.

“Bye Quinn,” Harry says to the air in front of him, then sighs and trudges onto the field to get yelled at by Angelina. Ginny doesn’t seem too pleased either, and Romilda has a look on her face like she’s seriously considering hitting the bludgers towards him rather than away from him.

~

Harry doesn’t tell anyone about Quinn’s cryptic instructions. Mostly because he’s decided to go see what all the fuss is about, and he knows all of them will advise him against making his relationship with Snape worse than it already is, if that’s even possible. He sneaks out of the common room that night, and luckily he does that basically every night anyway, so no one questions it. Even Ron doesn’t say anything, probably assuming he’s off to see Draco.

If no one asks him any questions, then it’s not like he’s lying, right?

Getting into the potions classroom takes no more than an alohamora, and what’s the point of that anyway, the only people that those level of locking spells keep out are toddlers and muggles, neither of which are roaming Hogwarts’s halls. He goes to the storage room in the back, which isn’t even locked, and that leaves him standing in front of the closet in the back, the one that’s locked away from all of them. “Hemlock.”

There’s a series of clicks, then the door creaks open. The shelves are lined with rare and expensive ingredients that he can barely name, but in the corner of the shelf that’s perfectly at eye level is exactly what Quinn said there would be - a large bowl filled with shining liquid. He leans over, and it almost reminds him of unicorn blood, which doesn’t exactly encourage him to dunk his face in it.

But Quinn wouldn’t trick him or do anything to hurt him, and he’s already here. He might as well.

He doesn’t even get past the tip of his nose before he’s falling, pressing through the liquid to land, stumbling, to his feet. He’s standing outside the castle, which what the hell, but everything looks washed out and faded. And, wait, it’s light out. But it was just the middle of the night.

“Hey, Lils, over here!” someone calls out, and for a moment Harry turns and thinks he’s looking at his double.

Wait. That’s Sirius draped over his double’s shoulders, and Remus rolling his eyes, and even Peter is there, laughing and light, looking nothing like the sniveling man Harry had seen before, but definitely him.

Which means that man is his father.

“Sod off,” a girl’s voice snaps, and Harry turns to see a young woman with fiery red hair and glaring green eyes. His eyes. “I saw what you did to Sev yesterday. Really? You haven’t outgrown this yet?”

“Snivelius is an asshole,” Sirius says while James’s face drops. “I thought you weren’t friends anymore, anyway.”

“It’s not that simple. And that doesn’t matter, I don’t need to be his friend to be intolerant of your bullying. I don’t condone it when he does it, so I don’t know why you think you’d get a free pass. I thought you’d grown up,” she says sharply, tossing her hair over her shoulder before walking away from them. His father scrambles to his feet and goes chasing after her.

Harry turns around and is face to face with Snape, barely an inch between them.

He only has a moment to be terrified before he realizes that Snape is young here too, maybe in his sixth or seventh year, and still wearing a Slytherin student uniform. He’s half ducked behind a tree, watching them and rubbing at his arm, where Harry knows his dark mark is. Harry is standing right in front of him, but he’s not reacting at all, instead looking through him.

These are Snape’s memories.

He’s no sooner figured that out when everything shifts again. He’s in a hallway, and it’s even one he recognizes. “Why didn’t you join me?” his mother asks, and she’s so little, she has to be a first year. “We said we were going to be together!”

She’s glaring at an equally small Snape, who just shrugs, looking down as he scuffs his foot against the ground. “The hat told me I would do well in Slytherin.”

“Well, then I should be in Slytherin too!” she says, grabbing his hand and attempting to tug him down the hall. “Come on, we’ll go to Dumbledore right now and make him resort me!”

“Lily, please,” Snape says, voice gentler than Harry’s ever heard it. He didn’t know Snape could sound like that. “You’ll do great in Gryffindor. You’re going to make so many new friends.”

“I don’t want new friends!” she snaps, then sniffs, rubbing her arm across her eyes. “I don’t like it here. Everything is strange, and different. Everything except you.”

His mum and Snape were friends? Childhood best friends, from the sound of it. How - how is this possible? How could he not know this?

Snape looks so sad staring at his mum, like seeing her upset is breaking his heart, but he pushes that away when she turns to look at him. “We’ll be fine. We’ll see each other every day. Nothing will change.”

“You should have been in Gryffindor with me!” she says, but her shoulders are slumped, resigned.

He smiles at her and flicks her nose. “Bravery isn’t really my thing, you know that. You’ve always been the brave one.”

The scene ripples, but it’s the same hallway, he hasn’t moved at all. He’s confused until he turns and sees Snape towering over his mother, furious. Lily glares right back, not giving an inch. They look the same age as him now, fourth or fifth year. “Potter? Really?”

“What do you care,” she snaps. “It’s none of your business.”

“Are you punishing me for not going to the dance with you last year?” he asks. “It’s not my fault that Bella asked me first. Besides, you know none of your friends like me, they would have been miserable if I’d gone with you, and that would have made you miserable, which would have made me miserable, and no one would have had any fun at all.”

“You shouldn’t have said yes to Bella in the first place! Of course I was going to ask you!” She shakes her head. “James isn’t about you. Not everything is about you, Sev. This is about me, and what I want.”

Snape crosses his arms over his chest. “Him? Really? The guy who’s been torturing me for years? I thought you had higher standards that that.”

She goes red with anger, marching forward until Snape is forced to take several steps back. “I don’t want to hear this from you. James has changed. You have too, but not for the better. Hanging out with Bella and that crowd. You know what they say about me, about muggles, about all of it. You hang out with people who would sooner see me dead than say hello to me, but I’m the monster here. Give me a break.”

“They’re not like that,” he defends. “They’re my friends. Your friends hate me, and I don’t ask you to stop hanging out with them.”

“No,” she says, a strange look on her face, “and you never have, have you?”

They freeze, and the scene shifts. Harry feels like he’s drowning. The way his mum was talking - is it possible that she and - no, of course not, he’s being ridiculous.

He’s in a playground, a muggle playground, and he doesn’t understand. Why would Snape be here? What memory could he have?

“Tuney, wait for me!” a child’s voice calls out, and a little girl with dark hair and a sharp chin runs past him, laughing, and then a moment later a girl with her red hair in pigtails follows, yelling out for the first girl to slow down. They can’t be more than six. That’s his mum and Aunt Petunia. But that makes even less sense. How can Snape have memories of this?

Lily trips and goes tumbling to the ground, but Petunia doesn’t notice, still running forward. Harry moves to help her up before remembering this is a memory and that he can’t do anything at all.

A little boy with dark hair and hand me down clothes jumps down from the swings and runs over. “Are you okay?” he calls out, stopping in front of her and sticking out his hand for her to grab. “Stand up, you’re okay, it’s just your knee. I scrape my knees all the time.”

She sniffles, looking up with tear filled eyes. She stares at him for a long moment before placing her hand in his.

They both let go with cries of pain, each of them reaching for their right forearms. His mother rips her jacket off, and at first Harry thinks she’s bruised, but then he realizes dotted across her arm are pale purple hydrangea blossoms. The boy shoves up his sleeve, and in the same place he has a delicate yellow rain lily.

“That’s me!” his mother says excitedly, grabbing onto the boy’s arm, “You’re mine! I’m Lily! That’s my name!”

The boy blinks, then grins, putting his hand over hers. “Hi Lily. I’m Severus.”

“Sever - Sev - Ros - Sefrus,” she says, stumbling over her words and getting more frustrated with herself each time.

He throws his head back and laughs, and she purses her lips and puffs out her cheeks, doing a great impression of a puffer fish. “You can just call me Sev.”

“Sev,” she says, satisfied, as they clasp each other’s arms and smile.

The scene dissolves, but Harry can’t quite believe it, this can’t be real. Snape and his mother were - she’s his - it’s just not possible!

The scene solidifies again, and he’s standing in the ruins of a home, a whole wall blown open. He doesn’t understand where he is or what’s going on until he sees a crib, and a baby with green eyes and a bloody forehead.

That’s him. This is the night his parents died. Why was Snape here?

“Lily!” Harry turns to see Snape frantically searching through the wreckage, pulling wood and glass aside, his hands turning bloody. “Lily, are you here? Say something!” He grabs onto a piece of glass, and curses, a deep gash forming down the center of his palm. “Where’s Potter? Where’s your kid?” He swallows, rubbing one of his bloody hands over his face. “Maybe everything’s fine and they all got away and the reason your point me spell isn’t working is because they’re under a powerful protection charm, and you’re acting like an idiot for no reason.”

Snape can’t see him - baby him - from across the room, and he isn’t crying. He’s just sitting in his crib, green eyes wide and watching, and from where Snape is he wouldn’t be able to see him unless he walked over and looked. Snape kicks one of the boards, and it reveals a single pale out flung hand. Snape turns an alarming shade of white, and Harry has to look away while Snape digs out his mother’s body.

“No,” he says, tone completely normal, and Harry risks a glance up. Snape is just sitting by his mother, his hands hovering over her like he wants to help her, to gather her up in his arms and fix her, but he doesn’t know where to start. Probably because there’s nowhere to start. She’s not sick. She’s dead. “No, this can’t - the whole bloody point of Potter is that he’s supposed to protect you, what use is he-” Snape pushes himself to his feet and goes through the house, shouting, “Potter! Where are you? It’s Severus! I mean, it’s Snape!” He shakes his head, muttering to himself, “Idiot, he’d probably taken the kid and ran - why didn’t he give the kid to her, why leave her behind to fight, even if she is a,” he stumbles, tripping over something, and Harry and Snape look down at the same time.

Lying dead on the ground is his father.

“James,” Snape breathes, looking genuinely horrified for a man who professed to hate his father so much. He stands there for several long moments, doing nothing at all, then his head snaps up. “The baby!”

He runs back upstairs, barely glancing at his mother’s body. He starts pushing boards aside, just as frantic as he was before, face ashen pale except where his blood is smeared across it. Harry wants to tell him that he’s not in there, that he’s not buried by wood and glass, but he can’t.

“Ma,” his baby self gurgles, reaching out pudgy hands towards Lily. “Ma!”

Snape freezes and stands up, finally peering into the crib. His baby self smiles when he sees Snape and holds up his hands. “Up! Ma!”

He slumps, holding onto the sides of the crib so tightly the whole thing creaks. His shoulder shake, and Harry comes to the uncomfortable realization that he’s seeing his horrible potions professor cry.

There’s no safe place to look, either Snape’s tears or his mother’s body, and he hates this, he can’t do this anymore.

Snape is digging his fingers into his arm, where his dark mark is. Where his soulmark is. There’s a bright silver light through the window, then a swan patronus is standing before him. A voice he doesn’t recognize says, “Something has happened to the Dark Lord. Everyone meet at the Lestranges.” Then the swan disappears.

Snape rubs his hand over his face, looking so tired that Harry can’t help but feel a twinge of sympathy. He takes out his wand and casts, “Expecto patronum!”

Nothing happens.

His eyes narrow and tries again. “Expecto patronum!”

Nothing. Snape curses, smacking his hand against the side of the crib. Baby Harry latches onto his hand, using it to pull himself upright. “MA!” he demands.

Harry’s expecting Snape to snatch his hand away, or yell at him, or something. But instead he just stares at him, looking into his eyes. He says softly, “Expecto patronum.”

A bright silver doe bursts from his wand, prancing around the destroyed room before coming to stand back by them. “Go to Dumbledore. Give him this message: The Potters are dead. Harry is alive. I have to - I have to go, but the child is here.”

The doe nods and disappears in a burst of light. Snape looks down at his baby self and uses the edge of his sleeve to clean the blood off his forehead, so only a small lighting bolt wound remains. It’s not even bleeding anymore. “You have her eyes,” he says softly. He steps away, throws his shoulders back, and casts, “Protego!”

Harry blinks from the burst of bright blue light. What could he be casting that on -

Snape apparates away, and the memory starts to dissolve around him. Harry just barely gets a chance to see his crib enveloped in a thick magical shield before he’s pulled into the next one.

He can’t do this anymore. He gets it, he understands, he saw what Quinn wanted him to see - more than ze probably intended, since he assumes Quinn figured everything out way faster than he did. He needs to get out of here.

He’s in the potions classroom, his mum and Snape partnered together in the front of the class, and they can’t be more than thirteen. They’re smiling and nudging each other with their elbows, and Harry can’t, he really can’t, he can’t watch Snape and his mother be friends after watching Snape finding her dead.

“OUT!” he shouts, his magic itching and crawling under his skin, “Stop it, stop all of it, get me out of -”

There’s a pulling in his navel, not unlike traveling by portkey, and then he’s lying flat on his back in the middle of the storage closet, the bowl sitting exactly where it was before.

He raises a hand to his face and is unsurprised to find that he’s crying.

~

Draco is confused when Harry doesn’t show up to potions class. He saw him this morning, and it’s not like he’s sick or anything, since Draco just came from the hospital wing, trying to squeeze in some extra training with Poppy.  He glances at Hermione and Ron, but they both shake their heads. Neville looks just as concerned as he feels.

“No Mr. Potter today?” Snape asks coolly, “A pity. That will be a zero for him across the board then.”

Ron glares, and Draco’s pretty sure Hermione’s hand on his arm is all that stops from saying something stupid.

Harry’s potions grade really can’t afford for him to skip class. What could he possibly be doing?

~

Harry has discovered something that he’s never, ever going to tell Hermione.

“You’re sure no one saw you?” he asks.

Dobby nods, his big ears flapping against his face. “Not a one, Mister Harry! Dobby is being sneaky!”

“And you’re sure you won’t get caught?” The last thing he wants is to get Dobby in trouble.

“I is sure,” he says. “I is not being sure that getting you that book is being a good idea.”

House elves shelve the books in the library. That means they can take books from the restricted section without having to check them out.

“It’s a better idea than me trying this without having any idea what I’m doing,” he points out. He hadn’t slept at all since seeing Snape’s memories, still trying to process everything. He thinks he’s mostly managed to keep everyone from suspecting anything this morning, but he couldn’t bring himself to go to potions class, can’t make himself go and face Snape. Not yet.

He hasn’t told anyone what he’s seen, and it’s killing him. He’s keeping so many secrets from so many people, but he’s not supposed to keep secrets from Ron, Hermione, Pansy, and Blaise. From Draco. He doesn’t like keeping secrets from them, and he knows if anything talking it out with them will only help.

But there’s something he needs to do first. It’s too bad Umbridge is spying on the mail and floo network, otherwise he wouldn’t have to go quite this far.  

“Keep watch for me, okay?” he asks.

“Yes, Mister Harry,” Dobby says, looking disapproving. Harry hopes that he doesn’t tell Winky about this, because then she’ll tell Draco, and it’s so much better if this comes from him. But he can’t ask him not to say anything, because that feels a little too much like keeping secrets.

He flips through the book, and the spell looks easy. He did this before without a spell or wand or anything at all, surely doing it properly will only make it easier?

Well, there’s one way to find out. He climbs into his bed, lays back, and brings his wand to his chest. He thinks of his bedroom back home, closes his eyes, and casts, “Proiectura!”

Nothing.

He sighs, pushing himself up to check the book again, and blinks. The dorm room and Dobby are gone, and he’s in his bedroom, cream linens and the bright Indian sky over his ceiling. He looks down, and he’s see through, here but not here.

“Yes!” he shouts, punching his hands into the air. He doesn’t have much time, so he scrambles out of his room and shouts, “Kreacher!”

There’s a pop, and Kreacher narrows his eyes. “Young Master is being bad!”

“Yell at me later. Where are Sirius and Remus?”

He glares and crosses his arms, but grudgingly says, “They is being in the sitting room.”

“Thanks!” He runs down the hall, leaping over the stair banister onto the floor below. He doesn’t even make a sound as he touches the ground. He’s managing to stand and walk just fine, but he can’t figure out how to open the door, so he just phases through it.

Sirius and Remus are bent over a large unfurled map. Which, now that he’s looking at it, almost look like blueprints. Wait, Remus has an ink brush in his hand, so they’re making some blueprints. House renovations? He hopes not, Kreacher will throw a fit. Sirius looks up and pales. “Harry! What are you doing?”

“Harry?” Remus mutters as he tears his eyes away from the parchment. He looks up, blinks, then shouts, “Harry!”

“Okay, yes, this is dangerous and illegal and you said not to do it,” he says, “but we need to talk.”

“Send us a bloody letter!” Sirius roars. “We explicitly told you not to this, now stop right now before you hurt yourself -”

 “Why didn’t you tell me that Snape and my mum were soulmates?” he interrupts.

Sirius’s mouth drops open. Remus breathes, “Oh shit.”

“I’m not sure why you’d say that,” Sirius begins.

“I saw it,” he snaps. “In this glowing bowl thing his storage - you know what, it doesn’t matter, don’t lie to me. Snape has a yellow rain lily mark on his left forearm, and my mum had purple hydrangeas on hers. Didn’t you think Snape being my mum’s soulmate might have been something I should know?”

“You looked in Snape’s pensieve,” Remus sighs. “That was a gross invasion of his privacy.”

“It wasn’t my idea,” he protests. “But that’s not really the point here.”

Sirius runs his hand through his hair. “What does it matter, really? It was just a mark on their skin to them. Not - look, obviously Remus and I worked out, and we’re very happy together. But not all soulmates are like that. Look at Tonks and your friend Cedric.”

“Severus made a lot of mistakes,” Remus says gently, “He - he chose a different path.”

“He joined those psychopaths who ended up killing so many of our friends, you mean,” Sirius says.

Remus shoots him a warning look. “It wasn’t that simple, and you know that.”

Harry shakes his head. “No. They were friends. They were best friends, and I saw - Snape was there the night they died, he went looking for them and he left a shield over my crib when he had to go-”

“That was him?” Sirius asks, looking genuinely surprised.

Remus lays his hand on Sirius’s back. “Look, Harry, we didn’t tell you because we didn’t want you to - to think that Severus is someone he isn’t, or to think that your parents weren’t in love. They were. Severus and Lily kept their soulmarks close to their chest even before everything fell apart, but James knew from the beginning. Lily and Severus weren’t ever in love, and they never dated. They were friends once, and that’s it.”

Remus and Sirius really seem to believe everything they’re saying, but - but Harry saw them, saw the way his mum acted around Snape, saw the way he would look at her when she wasn’t looking at him, and he doesn’t understand how things could have gone so horribly wrong. He believes them when they say that his parents were in love, that they were genuinely happy and besotted with one another.

But, as much as he’d like it to be true, he doesn’t think things between his mum and Snape were as clear cut as Sirius and Remus are saying it was. But if that’s what they believe, then it’s not like him telling them they’re wrong will help anything. “Okay.”

“Okay?” Remus asks, uncertain.

“Yeah,” he says, swallowing. “It’s - it’s okay, I’m okay. So. Okay.”

Neither of them look like they believe him, but Sirius only says, “Harry, please. We can find a way to talk more about this later. But you have to stop, you have to go back, this is dangerous.”

Harry feels like they don’t properly appreciate how many incredibly dangerous situations he’s found himself in, and how this doesn’t even make the list. But telling them that won’t help his position at all.

“We love you,” Remus says, reaching for him, but pausing when he remembers that he can’t touch him. “Please don’t astral project again.”

This part is easy, at least. “I love you too.”

He breaks the spell without responding to the second part. He doesn’t like making promises that he doesn’t intend to keep.

~

Something happened.

Draco doesn’t know what, exactly, but Trelawney get fired right in front of them, and is replaced with a centaur of all things, and Harry barely even blinks. He’s been acting dazed and quiet for days, and there are lot of things that could be taking up his soulmate’s mind right now, and he just shakes his head whenever any of them ask him if he wants to talk about it, but this is ridiculous.

Just the six of them are meeting up tonight, and Draco’s going to get some answers if it kills him.

It turns out he doesn’t have to, because they’ve no sooner walked through the door than Pansy snaps, “Okay, what’s your problem? Skipping potions? Are you trying to fail? You know Snape isn’t going to accept your late work or give you partial credit on anything.”

Harry rubs the back of his neck. “Sorry, I know. I just wasn’t ready to deal with him.”

“Why?” Ron asks, eyebrows pushed together. “What are you talking about?”

Harry looks nervous, of all things, which makes Draco nervous. They’ve been through so much shit these past few years, what could he possibly have to tell them that would make him nervous? He’s pretty sure they’re all immune to surprises at this point.

“Snape and my mum were soulmates.”

Blaise swears, Hermione is horrified, and Pansy and Ron look like they’re contemplating murder.

Draco has to fight the urge to sit down.

He was wrong. Clearly.

~

Harry ends up having to explain the whole thing twice, which is less horrifying than he thought it’d be, and actually, he was being stupid, he should have told them all immediately, because even just describing it to them makes him feel better.

“So what?” Ron says. “Remus and Sirius were right. Who cares if what they had on their arms? Snape maybe wasn’t born being awful, and so he and your mum were friends. But what he was doesn’t change what he is. Which is a bastard.”

“Your mother married your father, and she had you, and maybe she and Snape were alike,” Pansy allows, “Quinn gets along with him, he’s clearly not all awful, but there’s a big difference between being soulmates and being in love. Would you still love Draco if your soulmate was Ron?”

Harry looks over to Draco, who smiles at him, and he can’t imagine giving him up for anything or anyone, even if their marks disappeared tomorrow it wouldn’t matter to Harry. Draco is Draco, and that doesn’t have anything to do with the marks on their hips. “Yeah.”

“See?” Pansy says. “Who cares if your mum had a soulmate who wasn’t your dad? Bit unfortunate for all involved that it’s Snape, but at the end of the day, that’s not what’s important. You know that.”

They’re making a lot of sense. “Okay, yeah, you’re right. Still a bit weird that Snape was friends with my mum, though.”

“It’s very weird,” Blaise says. “But as far as your life goes, does it even rank?”

He has to take a moment to think about that. He wants to say yes instinctually, but really? “No.”

“See? Not a big deal at all,” Hermione says, but he knows her, and she’s definitely thinking something that she’s not sharing.

He raises an eyebrow and waits.

She bites her lower lip and looks to Ron seemingly without thinking about it. He shrugs, and she continues, “It just – it just makes him a little more awful, doesn’t it? He was your mum’s soulmate. Even if he was in love with her, or if they ever dated or something – you’re his soulmate’s son. He should have looked out of you, he should have at least been nice to you. Or, okay, I know he’s saved your life a couple of times, and maybe he’s not evil, but he’s not, he’s not kind.” She says in a small voice, “I think, even if I was bitter and alone, I would try and be kind. Just a little.”

“Snape’s an asshole,” Ron says, “which we’ve always known. It’s just possible that we may have to consider the possibility that he didn’t leave the womb hurling insults and he maybe once knew how to be a person. Which is a truth I personally would have been happy to never have confronted, but at the end of the day, I still want to punch him in the face. Or even maybe just knee him in the groin and run away, I’m not picky.”

Harry snorts, which turns into a giggle, and then he’s laughing so hard his stomach hurts while Draco pokes him in the side and tells him to pull it together, and everyone’s smiling, and really, truly, he’s an idiot. This is why he doesn’t keep secrets from his friends.

~

Draco understands the importance of learning the patronus charm, but he’s not looking forward to it. He’s known for being good at charms, and more than a couple of people have figured out that he’s been taking lessons from Poppy on the sly, and it’s going to be deeply embarrassing for him when he struggles with this charm in front of them. He works so hard to maintain his reputation as being good at charms, at being bloody brilliant at them, and even though it’s an advanced charm that most full grown wizards can’t cast, it still makes him uncomfortable that it’s something he can’t do.

“Focus on your happiest memory,” Harry instructs, his voice echoing around the chamber. He’s spent most of the session having them review everything they’d done before break, and he’s just finished explaining the basics of the charm. There are a couple of people missing, which Draco can’t help but think was foolish. This really isn’t the session to miss, but it does at least mean things are moving a little more quickly than usual. As it is, they don’t have much time to practice if they want to get to bed at a reasonable hour. “It can’t be something small, like a good test score or your favorite birthday present. It has to be something more, something deeper and more meaningful than anything like that. Often it’s a simple moment, a conversation or a kiss. Don’t mistake excitement for happiness, because they’re not the same. Hold that memory in your mind, but don’t just think of that memory. Try to relive it, as vividly and honestly as you can. Then point your wand in the air and cast. Remember, there are no special wand movements for this charm. It’s all mental.”

Draco can hear everyone casting around him, and he’s tempted too look around and see how they’re doing, to see what he has to compare himself against. But he knows that’s not going to help anyone, least of all himself. He ignores everyone’s cries of excitement and disappointment and closes his eyes. His happiest memory. What’s his happiest memory?

There’s all those moments with Harry, his friends, his parents. But he’s tried so many of those before, back in third year, and sure, he has more of them now, but how are they different? If they didn’t work before, he doesn’t see why they would work now. Maybe he needs a different kind of happiness.

He remembers the night of Triwizard Tournament, and he thinks past the fear, past the uncertainty and worry. He remembers holding Harry in his arms, seeing Fleur protecting all of them, finding Cho and Cedric alive. He remembers his clawing desperation as he used healing spells he’d never tried before on his father, snatching him back from the edge of death. He remembers his mother’s hysteria folding into calm, her silent acceptance and support at his back as he performed spells she hadn’t thought he knew the words for. He remembers his father opening his eyes and telling him that he did it for him, that what he valued even more than his own safety was Draco’s good opinion.

It’s not a soft happiness. It’s jagged and painful, but it’s real, in a way all his other hazily pleasant memories aren’t.

He holds that feeling in his mind, exhausted and afraid with his father’s blood drying under his fingernails, but sure in the knowledge everyone he cared about was as at that moment as safe as he could make them. “Expecto patronum!”

He feels his magic tighten, then expand, and a hush falls over everyone. He hopes he just hasn’t made something embarrassing and they’re all doing their best not to laugh at him, like a little cloud of patronus mist that won’t do him any good at all.

When he opens his eyes, he sees something bright and silvery right in front of him. He has to take several steps back, and then he’s laughing, part genuine amusement and part relief.

A large silvery peacock cocks his head to the side, so well formed that Draco can see the different pattern of feathers on his chest, to say nothing of his tail feathers, which are even taller than Draco. Clearly he’s improved since third year.

“Brilliant,” Cedric breaths, looking honestly impressed.

Cho nods, eyes wide. “Draco, that’s wonderful!”

Blaise snorts, and Pansy laughs, calling out, “Of course it’s a peacock!”

“What are you implying?” he asks, eyes narrowed. His patronus snaps his beak at her, and then his long tail feathers fold together so they’re narrow, and he spreads his wings, flying around the roof of the chamber. Even Pansy stops laughing long enough to look impressed, and he wants to look at Harry so badly, to see his proud smile and soft eyes, but in the middle of the RA is nowhere close to private, so it’ll have to wait.

Of course, a moment so nice can’t last.

There are two pops and Winky and Dobby are standing next to Harry. “You must be going!” Dobby says urgently. “Miss Umbridge knows where you are!”

Everyone pales. Draco dismisses his patronus.

Harry shakes his head. “She can’t. How? And even if she knows, she can’t get in. I closed the entrance behind everyone.”

“Unless she has a Parselmouth with her,” Luna says. “You’re not the only one, after all.”

Hermione frowns. “Does she? I thought Harry was the only British Parselmouth.”

“That we know of,” George points out.

Cassius adds, “There’s rumors of a couple in Africa, at least.”

Draco can’t see Umbridge being on good enough terms with any foreign nation to borrow one of their Parselmouths.

“She is not using a snake speaker,” his house elf says darkly.

“Winky, speak plainly,” he orders.

Just as he finishes talking, there’s a boom, and the whole chamber shakes, dust falling from the ceiling, as if they’re in the middle of an earthquake. Everyone stumbles, and some people scream.

Hermione clings to Ron’s arm to stay upright. All the quidditch players shift their weight with the tremors, but everyone else is struggling. Ron says grimly, “She doesn’t need a parselmouth. She’s going to force her way in.”

There’s another great echoing boom, and Draco’s really starting to panic when things go from bad to worse. The statue of Zarathurstra groans, and its mouth falls open.

Oh, shit.

“It’s okay!” Draco shouts.

Nagini slithers out first, and people are already screaming when they see her. They should have saved it, because when Theophania follows her, fangs bared, they have no screams left to give.

~

Harry curses. They really should have mentioned the couple deadly magical snakes they were sharing space with before now, but in his defense, he hadn’t anticipated the chamber coming down on their heads.

“What is this? What are you doing?” Theophania demands. Her inner lids are still closed at least. “Stop! Right now!”

“It’s not us,” he tells her, ignoring the startled glances he gets when the Parseltongue leaves his mouth. He barely registers his friends telling everyone to calm down and put their wands away. That’s good. The last thing they need is for someone to start attacking Theophania. “The person we were hiding from has found us. She’s trying to get in.”

“She’ll break the chamber! My Salazar’s chamber!” she roars. “Fix it!”

Fix it? How’s he supposed to fix this, he doesn’t even know what she’s doing, exactly.

Nagini has slithered over to Draco and curled around his feet. She says, “The children need to go, especially these ones. They can’t be found. My former human will be angry if he discovers they lied to him.”

“I don’t care about the children!” Theophania shouts, towering over Nagini and Draco both. Neither of them look as afraid as Harry thinks they should. Another terrifying bang and the echo of breaking stone shudders through the chamber. Whatever Umbridge is doing, it’s working. She’s either getting closer, or she’s planning to collapse the chamber with them still inside.

Nagini looks into her milky eyes for a long beat, then says, “Your human would have wanted you to care.”

Theophania curls back as if she’s been struck, but neither of them look away from the other.

Harry is surrounded by far too many beings that are comfortable having staring contests with a basilisk. “Nagini is right, we need to at least get the Slytherins out of here, it’s important.” Also, he’d like for none of them to die, if possible, that would be nice too.

Theophania swings her massive head around to look at him. She bares her fangs, the venom dripping off of them and landing precariously close to where he’s standing. “I will get them away. But you must stop this. If I save the children, you must save my Salazar’s chamber.” She hesitates, and it’s wrong to see indecision on her, she’s far too old and powerful to second guess herself. “It’s the only part of him I have left.”

Well, fuck. “Okay,” he says. He’ll just have to do – he doesn’t know, something. He can’t let Umbridge either find or destroy the chamber, because the former will inevitable lead to the latter. “How are you going to get them out of here?”
