“The same way I get myself out,” she answers, lowering her head and laying her body flat on the ground.

“Pipes,” he says in English. He looks to the RA, who are afraid and uncertain. “Get on her back, she’ll get you out of here.” Everyone looks at him like he’s crazy, which isn’t new, but they don’t have time for it right now. “Trust her. Or me. Trust someone, and go.”

Draco runs the palm of his hand over Nagini’s head, then steps over her. He clambers onto Theophania’s back without hesitation, then looks down and holds out his hand to the person closest to him, who happens to be Colin Creevey. “Come on,” he says.

Colin swallows, but takes Draco’s hand and lets himself be hauled up beind him. He wraps an arm around Draco’s waist, then holds out his free hand for the next person. That gets everyone moving, people climbing onto Theophania’s back and helping anyone who struggles on her smooth scales.

“What about you?” Neville asks.

Harry shakes his head. “Don’t worry about me. I’m going to stop this.”

“How?” Ron snaps.

He shrugs. “I’ll think of something, I always do.”

Hermione scowls. None of them look impressed.

“We is knowing how to help!” Dobby says excitedly. “We is being right back!”

Winky glares at them. “We will help. But everyone who is not Mister Harry must be going. The more people there is being, the less safe it is.”

“You can’t be serious.” Hermione says.

Winky shrugs. “I am going to get things to help. Do not be making this harder.”

They disappear with a crack, and Hermione snarls. Ron searches Harry’s face, nods once, then snags her elbow and drags her towards Theophania. “Come on, let’s go.”

“Have you lost your mind?” she screeches.

Neville sighs, claps Harry on the shoulder, and goes jogging after them.

“Dobby won’t let anything happen to Harry,” Ron says patiently as he lifts Hermione onto Theophania’s back, like she weighs nothing at all. Hermione’s whole face is red, but Harry thinks its mostly indignation. “Worst case scenario, he’ll just snap them both Hogsmeade.”

Hermione still looks pissed off as Theophania starts moving, slithering her massive body from side to side and deeper into the chamber, where it connects to the pipes that are large enough for her to fit through. He hopes someone reminds them all to duck.

He only has a moment to stand around uselessly when there’s a crack, and then screaming. It’s Dobby, but not just him, the book in his hands is screaming too, a high pitched woman’s voice that fills the chamber. Dobby’s hands are smoking and there’s a horrible smell of burned flesh in the air as he digs his fingers into the binding.

“Dobby!” he yells, horrified. Harry grabs the book from his hands, and then has the split second thought that grabbing the corrosive book with his bare hands wasn’t maybe his smartest play.

But as soon as he touches it, the book stops screaming, and it doesn’t burn. The leather only feels warm and soft in his hands. He looks at the cover, but it’s blank. Then golden embossed symbols rise out of the leather, and hieroglyphics settle across it.

“Are you okay?” he asks, tearing his eyes away. “What is this? I can’t read it.”

Dobby nods, even though his hands are bloody and peeling. “You must look closer!”

“I can’t read this,” he insists. Dobby glares, which is a first, so Harry sighs and looks back down at the book. He’s just trying to figure out what a bird could mean when the symbols shift again, and curling golden calligraphy flows across the cover.

An Advanced Treatise on The Ancient Art of Necromancy

His stomach rolls. “Necromancy?”

 There’s a deep crack, and for a moment Harry worries he’s too late, and Umbridge is either about to burst though the chamber doors or the ceiling is about to collapse on his head. Instead Winky appears in front of him, and behind her is a small mountain of animal skeletons, all the animals Theophania had lived on during her thousand years alone and forgotten under the castle. “I told you I is saving them for when you be needing them,” she says, pleased.

“I,” he looks between the skeletons and the book. “What do you expect me to do? I can’t – I’m not – I don’t know what you want me to do with this. I don’t even know any necromancy spells. Just the one ghost summoning one I messed up.” This is so much more dangerous and illegal than astral projecting. Sirius and Remus are going to ground him forever.

“Use the book,” Dobby urges.

“How? Is there a chapter on mass reanimation?” he asks, frustrated.

The books snaps open in his hands. Words flow across the page, and for a moment they look like what he thinks might be Mycenean Greek before it all shifts to English.

It’s a single paragraph, barely four sentences. It’s a list of wand movements, then a spell. There’s ominous creaking, and then the ground shakes again, so much so that the tower of animal skeletons fall over and the house elves grab onto his legs for balance.

He’s running out of time. He really, really wishes he had a better idea, but, well, he doesn’t. He told Theophania that he’d keep Salazar Slytherin’s chamber safe, so that’s what he’s going to do. Hopefully. It’s at least what he’s going to try to do.

He reads over the wand movements twice, practices it for about a minute, and really wishes the book had literally any other instructions. But it doesn’t.

Harry raises his wand, circles the pile of bones twice, then jabs his wand into the center. “Ola zontana!”

This time when everything shakes, it’s not because of Umbridge.

~

“I wish we had the map,” Milly mutters, and Draco can’t help but agree. Cedric and Susan give them an odd look, but they don’t ask. The Ravenclaws and Gryffindors had broken off to head up to the towers, but the Slytherins and Hufflepuffs are creeping along together back to their common rooms. They usually leave a few at a time from RA, since it’s very hard to be inconspicuous in this large of a group. If Filch comes across them, there’s nowhere to hide or any believable excuse they could give. Of course, they could always have Hermione obliviate Filch, her spells are usually more controlled than his anyway. He’s a bit leery of trying it a second time considering that he’s still not entirely sure how many memories he took from Snape in the shrieking shack.

They just have to cross the main hallway, then they can start heading down to the dungeons using the East corner staircase. It’s not one of the main staircases so it doesn’t move, and it’s narrow and makes everyone who uses it dizzy, which means they probably won’t cross paths with anyone. They just have to get to it.

“We’ll run across in groups of two,” Cedric says.

Susan shakes her head and whispers, “That’ll take too long, there are too many of us.”

Cedric frowns, but nods. “Okay, groups of three. Hide in the alcove near the hallway that leads to the herbology exit, wait a couple minutes, then proceed to the staircase. Understand?”

Everyone nods, and Draco’s about to tell Blaise, Pansy and Milly to go first when he hears something in the distance. Cedric holds up hand for silence, even though no one is talking, and his eyebrows dip together.  Draco asks, “Is that … what is that?”

They stand there a couple more moments, perplexed, then Cassius says, “I think it’s screaming. And, uh, rats? Something scurrying.”

What the hell.

Cedric shakes his head, clearly about to tell them all to ignore it, but then it gets louder. And closer.

Someone is screaming. Several somones are screaming. And they’re coming this way.

“Get back! Hide!” Draco snaps, and everyone rushes to get back into the shadows of their narrow hallway, flattening themselves against the wall. A couple smart people whisper spells to extinguish the nearby torches, giving them a little more darkness to hide in.

Draco watches the hallway, hoping that whoever’s screaming passes by without noticing them.

He really didn’t need to worry about that.

Thousands of animal skeletons with glowing green eyes rush down the hall, so many of them on top of and around each other that it’s just a river of bones barreling down the main hallway. Umbridge, a couple ministry officials, and several seventh years that Draco has never particularly liked are caught in the mass of bones, being carried along by all of them and unable to force themselves free. The river of animated skeletons blasts by them, including the screaming and crying people caught in their grasp, but it’s not until their shrieks are faint echoes that Draco feels safe leaning out into the main hallway. Cedric fists his hand in the back of his robe but doesn’t pull him back.

The entire hallway is empty. Or, well, mostly.

A single rabbit skeleton hops down the hall. It’s missing most of the bones from its right leg, leaving it’s hops lopsided and haphazard.

“I’m going to need so much therapy,” Cassius breaths.

Susan snorts. “They’re going to need so much therapy.”

“Can we go to our common rooms now?” Hannah asks plaintively. “I don’t think we have to sneak. If that didn’t raise any alarms, I don’t think we will.”

“Yeah, okay,” Cedric sighs, and they all walk into the hall.

At the same time, Perenelle and Nicolas Flamel turn the corner, wands out.

They stare at each other for a long moment, no one making a sound. Then Nicolas beams and says, “Lovely night for a stroll,” before turning on his heel and walking in the opposite direction. Perenelle sighs, gives them all a disproving look, then followers her husband.

Forget therapy. Draco needs a drink.
